dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HUM of a large refrigerator just audible over the sound of Indian music - MARGARET, briefly glimpsed pondering cartons of milk. The electronic PEEP of the cash til. A man on a mobile phone pushes past MARGARET, who takes her place second in the queue. The female shopkeeper piles newspapers on the counter in front of MARGARET. Distracted by images of the bombed hotel on the TV, she hesitates for beat.

dialogues.speaker: MAN BEHIND THE COUNTER
dialogues.text: One forty-nine please.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: How much is the milk?

dialogues.speaker: MAN BEHIND THE COUNTER
dialogues.text: Forty-nine pence. (taking the change) Thank you. MARGARET turns to leave, jostled by a tall young man wired into an ipod. EXT. STREET. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DAWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET heads down the busy street, shopping bag in hand. INT. KITCHEN. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET sits at breakfast with her husband DENIS, sipping tea. DENIS butters his toast. MARGARET shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Too much. Much too much butter.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: I like butter.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Milk’s gone up. MARGARET reaches for a jug, pouring milk into it, slidin it down on a table.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 49p a pint.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Good grief! We’ll have to economise. I suppose we could always sell the car. (chuckles ) Or take in paying guests! He scoops up the newspaper and glances towards the door -

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Watch out. She’s on the prowl. MARGARET looks beyond DENIS to a a sense of growing commotion. A concerned POLICE GUARD coming up the stairs meeting JUNE [early 60's] MARGARET’s carer, along a distant corridor, steady on the approach.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (to DENIS) Eat your egg. JUNE smiles with visible relief on seeing MARGARET, now sitting tapping open her egg.

dialogues.speaker: JUNE
dialogues.text: Goodness! There you are. JUNE's look of quiet concern.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes. MARGARET eats her egg.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here we are. But for JUNE, she is entirely alone. INT. CORRIDOR CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: JUNE
dialogues.text: I don’t understand how it happened, how could she possibly have got out? It’s very very important - MARGARET looks out of the kitchen. Her POV down the corridor of JUNE and the POLICEMAN and a CLEANER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please just make it really clear. Who’s on after you?

dialogues.speaker: POLICE GUARD
dialogues.text: Dixon. MARGARET slips away. INT.HALL. CHESTER SQUARE. DAY. MARGARET hurries through the hall. INT. BEDROOM. HOUSE. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT.DAY. A wide cupboard- MARGARET’s eyes move back along the rail in front of her, her fingers touch hanger after hanger of brown tweed and grey twill. JUNE goes over to the curtains, pulling them back, letting in the sunlight-

dialogues.speaker: JUNE
dialogues.text: Beautiful day. Oh, you’ve made a start. Carol’s coming soon, I'll get some bags. Anything you want to go to Mark, I'll bring up a suitcase for it. The smell of smoke lingering. Suddenly DENIS’ hand reaches across, wavering between jackets of brown tweed and grey twill- He reaches for a suit.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: No no no no. The grey.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (0.S)
dialogues.text: You sure? The swipe of a clothes brush, briefly seen, drawn across one sleeve-—

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes. Distant footsteps-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-Definitely the grey. JUNE returns, oblivious-—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Righty ho. Boss knows best. JUNE spies the newspaper, sees the photos of twisted carnage on the front page.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t let her take my paper away. JUNE reaches one hand out to scoop it up in passing-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Oh, I haven’t had a chance to look at that yet, dear.

dialogues.speaker: JUNE
dialogues.text: Sorry. JUNE hesitates, leaves the newspaper resting on the bed as she heads off with the suit on a hanger.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Atta-girl. DENIS smiles as he stands in the bathroom doorway, soaping his face with shaving cream- He hums to himself as he resumes shaving until-

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (0.8)
dialogues.text: Damn. MARGARET looks up, DENIS has nicked his chin-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Blot it...Blot it.. She turns, sees JUNE, through the ajar door, standing in the corridor, looking back at her

dialogues.speaker: JUNE
dialogues.text: Sorry ? INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DAY. A comfortable drawing room, filled with the photographs and memorabilia of a former political life. MARGARET stands by the window, half a dozen of DENIS’ ties in her hand. Pulling back the net curtain, MARGARET peers out-— Two POLICEMAN stand down below next to a Police BMW car. They are lost in conversation, pointing to the door, clearly concerned. One POLICE MAN nods to the other, a sense of the changin of the guard as he drives off in the BMW. SUDDENLY from behind-

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Now look what you’ve done. Are they to keep the loonies out or you in? MARGARET eyes DENIS, looking at her with wry smile -

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ll be off then.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Wear your scarf. There’s a chill out there. Suddenly looming over her and grinning down as if at the top of a tunnel SUSIE, MARGARET’s personal secretary carrying a cardboard box.

dialogues.speaker: SUSIE
dialogues.text: Good morning Lady Thatcher. Are you alright ? (concerned) How are you feeling ?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I'm fine, thank you Susie.

dialogues.speaker: SUSIE
dialogues.text: I’ve just been reading about the bombings.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes. Frightful. SUSIE’s mobile goes off. She fumbles in her bag to switch it off.

dialogues.speaker: SUSIE
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SUSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These are the books for you to sign. I brought as many as I could find. Shall we go through your appointments? MARGARET looks at her still nonplussed.

dialogues.speaker: SUSIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We said we’d go through them today.  MARGARET nods-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, dear. Today.

dialogues.speaker: SUSIE
dialogues.text: The invitation has come from Downing Street for the unveiling of your portrait. I’1l put it on the mantelpiece, and there’s an invitation from Lord Armstrong for lunch on the first Friday of next month. The murmur of SUSIE’s voice, a kind of white noise-

dialogues.speaker: SUSIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I said no because you've got a concert that afternoon but if you'd like to..?

dialogues.speaker: SUSIE, (O.S)
dialogues.text: .+.-It looks like a very interesting programme. MARGARET’s listens, oddly distracted-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: What are they playing? SUSIE looks at her momentarily at a loss then scrabbles back through the diary-

dialogues.speaker: SUSIE
dialogues.text: I think they said Rogers and Hammerstein. ‘SHALL WE DANCE’ FROM ‘THE KING & I” SUDDENLY BREAKING THROUGH AS IF FROM ANOTHER TIME CARRYING INTO.... INT. SADLER’S WELLS. LONDON. 1950. NIGHT. An orchestra in full flight- A programme for THE KING & I on a woman’s lap. A man’s hand reaches in and her hands slips into his. INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DAY. Whilst SUSIE shuffles through the arrangements at the desk in the background, MARGARET stands at the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silly man. MARGARET’s gaze, seeing DENIS just visible in the street below. He looks up, smiles,

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He hasn’t got his scarf on. MARGARET throws DENIS a half wave. In return, he twirls his umbrella and does a couple of steps of a Chaplin walk for her benefit before passing the Postman who is shuffling through his letters as he approaches the front step, below. SUSIE looks on with quiet concern. INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DAY. MARGARET’ is at her desk signing a stack of her memoirs, The Downing Street Years. MARGARET opens one, reaching for a pen. The curve of inky handwriting as she begins to sign them, Margaret Thatcher. Close on the swoop of the pen. Without missing a beat, she writes the name Margaret Roberts... The insistent blare of an air raid siren from another time cuts through - INT. BACK PARLOUR. SHOP. GRANTHAM. 1943. DUSK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rumble of an approaching air raid overhead- The STEADY SHAKE of the table legs all around pulls out to reveal- BEATRICE ROBERTS [early 50’s] austere, crouched next to MARGARET under a wide kitchen table along with ALFRED ROBERTS [early/mid 50's] a cumbersome man and MURIEL ROBERTS [21 yrs]. The sound of an air-raid siren.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: Did someone cover the butter? All look at one another in a panic.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I‘l1l go. Suddenly MARGARET scrabbles out from under the table, all look on with horror-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave it.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED, (CALLING AFTER)
dialogues.text: Margaret— INT. SHOP. GRANTHAM. 1943. DUSK. MARGARET scooping up the butter cover slamming it quickly over the thin slice of butter left in the butter dish before sliding it into the cold cupboard underneath the counter. SUDDENLY the shop illuminates- A DISTANT EXPLOSION. MARGARET momentarily paralyzed before, running back towards the back parlour to resume her place under the table. INT. BACK PARLOUR. SHOP. GRANTHAM. 1943. DUSK. MARGARET scrabbles underneath. ALFRED surreptitiously pats her arm.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good girl. She shrugs, flushing with pride.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, no matter what they do, it’1ll be business as usual. The DRONE of the air raid dissolving away- INT. SHOP, GRANTHAM. 1945. DAY. A boy and girl look on as MARGARET measures flour on the shop scales.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Two of the small beef, Mr. Roberts. MARGARET glances up at her father serving further down the counter.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What is the life blood of any community? It’s business....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALFRED on a small town hall stage behind a makeshift podium.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: Not just big business but small businesses, like mine. The SOFT press of MEN all around, MARGARET, a lone woman amongst them, peering over shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: (passing/hushed aside) Margaret! BEATRICE tuts, shoving a tray in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: CUPS
dialogues.text: MARGARET sinks a little, taking the tray, and glances back at ALFRED just visible on a stage.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: We on this island are strong. We're self-reliant. Sometimes we're plain bloody minded. NOW AT THE BACK OF THE HALL, holding a tray loaded with dirty cups, MARGARET watches her father, back turned to the kitchen filled with WOMEN and YOUNG GIRLS making tea and washing up cups.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But we also believe in helping each other. And I don’t mean by state hand-outs... EXT. STREET. GRANTHAM. 1943. DAY. MARGARET sweeps outside the shop, glancing across the street at- THREE PRETTY GIRLS dolled up for the evening and arms linked, crossing on the other side of the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: PRETTY YOUNG WOMAN 1
dialogues.text: Margaret, do you want to come to the pictures? MARGARET’s eyes catch on the glitter of a broach in passing. They turn to look at her WHISPERING and GIGGLING.  10

dialogues.speaker: PRETTY YOUNG WOMAN 2
dialogues.text: She can’t come, she’s got to study. The FLUSH of MARGARET’S skin -

dialogues.speaker: PRETTY YOUNG WOMAN 2, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Miss Hoity Toity! The STING OF EMBARRASSMENT.

dialogues.speaker: THE SENSE OF THE PRETTY GIRLS WHISPERING ABOUT HER, EYES
dialogues.text: TRAVELLING OVER her disparagingly.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Never run with the crowd, Margaret. Go your own way. The SWAY of a SKIRT as they walk away.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED OOV
dialogues.text: (close to) Open it then. INT. SHOP. GRANTHAM. 1943. DAY. Close on a telegram addressed to MARGARET ROBERTS, 1-3 North Parade, Grantham. MARGARET'S father ALFRED, watching.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (looking up) I’ve got a place at Oxford. ALFRED bear-hugs MARGARET awkwardly. INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DAY. MARGARET at her desk, the ghost of a smile.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: Don’t let me down Margaret. The CHINK of a teacup- MARGARET looks down the corridor in expectation at BEATRICE standing at the sink working the SQUEAK of the cloth against a stubborn tea stain.  11

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (calling out) Mother? BEATRICE comes down the corridor into the shop, wiping her hands on a cloth. ALFRED goes to hand BEATRICE the letter.

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: (shakes head) My hands are still damp. BEATRICE turns and walks back to where she came from. MARGARET looks back at the letter, heart bursting, trying to contain her joy. INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DAY. MARGARET looks down, pen in hand, the words Margaret Roberts newly signed in the front cover. She tears the page out. INT. BEDROOM. HOUSE. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT.DAY. MARGARET napping in bed. The still of the bedroom, caught in the half light of a late afternoon- A hand slides a teacup onto the bedside table - The flicker of MARGARET’s eyelids-

dialogues.speaker: BEATRICE
dialogues.text: (passing/hushed aside) Margaret! BEATRICE tuts, shoving a tray in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: PRESENT -
dialogues.text: MARGARET stirs again, blinking awake. DENIS sits by the window. He is bent over a pair of spectacles, wrapping wire around one of the arms with a pair of pliers. Other items of clothing of his are on Margaret’s couch.  12

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: (without taking his eyes of the job) They're talking about you again. The murmur of JUNE on the phone-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Sun’s not quite over the yard arm. Time for tea. A phone rings, O.S. MARGARET considers DENIS now wearing a pink turban and confronts the extraordinary head-gear.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: What have you got on your head? DENIS smiles, throwing back his head, the swathe of pink fabric from his turban hanging down ridiculously-

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Found it in the cupboard and thought bugger it, it’s Friday, why not fancy dress? MARGARET sits drinking her tea, JUNE’s hushed tones almost audible.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: You look ridiculous. MARGARET strains to hear-

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Bosslady no like? She makes a shushing motion.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (as if to a bad dog) No, Denis, Bosslady no like. MARGARET resumes listening. The door ajar, the sounds of life just audible outside-

dialogues.speaker: JUNE, (0.8)
dialogues.text: It’s taken Carol so long to get her to agree to this. She’s been so reluctant to let his things go. DENIS sinks onto the bed, bored.  13

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (without looking) Feet. He tuts and adjusts his legs so that his shoes don’t dirty the bedspread. MARGARET stands, ear pressed close to the open door-

dialogues.speaker: JUNE, (0.8)
dialogues.text: You can never be sure she’s taking her medication...I think sometimes she hides them..

dialogues.speaker: DENIS VO
dialogues.text: Oh, rumbled! MARGARET looks back at her cup of tea, spots two pills resting in the tea cup. She considers the pills, pops them in her mouth, drinks.

dialogues.speaker: JUNE, (0.8)
dialogues.text: She’s definitely more distracted than usual today. INT/EXT. BEDROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. DAY. A shout in the street. A woman’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL OOV
dialogues.text: Can I suggest you remove the sticker from the back of your car. Margaret looks through the net curtains and sees CAROL THATCHER[early 50’s] just visible stepping out of a taxi, remonstrating with the driver, clutching her purse and waving her credit card at him with rising irritation.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL OOV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well then take the sticker off! I call that false advertising! I would say keep the change, but there isn’t any change. INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DAY. A scotch being poured. The cap not quite going back on the whisky bottle. A frantic fumble for the remotes for the tv.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL OOV
dialogues.text: Hello June, any news? I’ve brought every bag I could find.  14 High shot of MARGARET sitting in a chair watching TV. As if she has been there a while. CAROL enters with suit carriers in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hello Ma. Bloody taxi driver. Wouldn’t take my card. I said don’t have a sticker saying you take Visa and then insist on cash. Can you believe it? I was rummaging around the bottom of my bag. He didn’t get a tip.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I didn’t know that you were dropping by today, dear.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (Dumping her stuff all over the place) Yes, you said yesterday...You wanted to make a start on Dad’s things. The cupboards ? Then I can help you dress. MARGARET, nonplussed.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’ve got Michael and-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Jaqueline...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Coming for dinner tonight.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Of course. (turning up the TV) We're having halibut. On TV, images of a bombed street,

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh God. Isn’t it terrible? MARGARET nods, both silently listening to the drone of the newscaster-—

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They think it’s Al Quaida - The charred remains of cars, desperate people running, a rescue operation midway- MARGARET blinks, inwardly reeling from the images-  15

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (V.0)
dialogues.text: Denis! Quick Flash: Denis in pyjamas, brushing his teeth in a hotel bathroom, glances at her through the open door.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: It’ll be fine. Come on, get your head down, it’s ten to three, for God's sake. EXT. GRAND HOTEL. BRIGHTON. 1984. NIGHT. Chaos outside the Grand Hotel in the aftermath of the bomb. The injured are pulled through the rubble.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS READER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: At ten to three this morning an explosion extensively damaged the Grand Hotel in Brighton, scene of the Conservative Party conference.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS READER 2, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...Where the Prime Minister and a number of her cabinet were staying. They escaped unhurt - The WHIR of SIRENS- The BLUR of FIRE ENGINE LIGHTS- The image of a BODY being stretchered out of the rubble by FIREFIGHTERS.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS READER 3, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Five people have died, many others are injured, some critically. The IRA have claimed responsibility. DENIS and MARGARET sit in their coats covering MARGARET’s evening dress and DENIS pyjamas. Both looking out in silent shock at the devastated Grand hotel, reflected on the glass of the car windows. MARGARET looks on with quiet, sobering despair, still numb with shock. DENIS looks at her. He grips her hand. They sit, fingers locked. INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DAY. Close on MARGARET’s hand and whisky glass. Shaking.  16

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (standing up) We must release a statement, offering our condolences.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m sure they’ve already-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: We must never, ever, ever give in to terrorists. MARGARET sees JUNE and CAROL exchange looks of ‘oh dear...’ INT.BEDROOM. HOUSE. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT.DUSK. MARGARET sits in a dressing gown at a dressing table, staring at her reflection. CAROL stands behind her, holding up several dresses.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Now ma, are we going long or just below the knee tonight?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Oh, below the knee I should think. She watches, irritated, as CAROL reaches to move a pile of DENIS’ clothes-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No! Don’t move those. I haven’t finished sorting them. CAROL settles beside her on a chair.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I hear you went out today...You mustn’t go out on your own Mummy. We've talked about that.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: There was no milk.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Call Robert he’1ll get it for you if June’s not up-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I am not for the knackers yet. From behind-

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (0.S)
dialogues.text: Now take it easy, Margaret.  17 DENIS just visible, perched on the bed, looks up from doing the crossword in the newspaper-—

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No one is saying that.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: If I can’t go out to buy a pint of milk then what is the world coming to. Really Carol, please don’t fuss about it. You’ve always been like this, fuss fuss fuss. You must find something better to do with your time. It’s most unattractive in a woman. When I was your age the last thing I wanted to do was fuss around my mother. Silence- CAROL, inwardly stung quietly busying herself, forcing all emotion away. MARGARET hesitates catching DENIS’ eye, with quiet warning.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Four down, 9 letters. DENIS withdraws into his crossword.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Something b something t something n...something something somthing...Refusal to change course-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Obstinate. DENIS writes, pleased. CAROL looks up, with quiet bemusement-—

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What? MARGARET deflects, pointing to a necklace in CAROL’s hands.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Pearls. I’ll wear the pearls. CAROL slips them onto MARGARET’S neck and fastens them.  18

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There they are. My little twins. Thank you, dear. INT. CORRIDOR. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. EVENING. The murmur of conversation- CAROL tails MARGARET, steady on the approach towards the drawing room.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It’s nearly all familiar faces, William, Michael and his lovely wife-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Jacqueline. CAROL smiles, clearly reassured-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: And then there’s Peter, James R and James T and that very nice man-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes-—

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: - we met last year.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes I remember-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I think he’s bringing his new lady friend just to mix it up a bit. We're rather short on women - but I’m sure we’ll manage-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I’ve always preferred the company of men- CAROL gestures ahead, MARGARET nods, reticent, yet forcing herself on, she hesitates at the door, her hand trembling on the handle.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Ma?  19 INT. CORRIDOR.DARTFORD. 1949. EVENING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close up of a shoe being rubbed on a calf. A young hand hesitating on a door handle. INT. SITTING ROOM. HOUSE. DARTFORD. 1949. EVENING. A 1950's drinks party- A bank of stuffy GREY SUITED MEN pontificating and their WIVES lost in a separate polite conversation-

dialogues.speaker: GREY SUITED MAN
dialogues.text: Ah, Miss Roberts. Hoping to be chosen as our candidate for parliament. A young MARGARET [24yrs] stylish in a suit, straight from work, stands clutching her handbag, oddly out of place amidst the neat 50’s chintz. A bank of sporting prints collage a wall. A bespectacled YOUNG DENIS THATCHER (30's) glances up from his drink, taking her in. INT.DINING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT.EVENING. The MURMUR of dinner party conversation-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Well I don’t like coalitions, never have... MARGARET’s POV of her fingers absently grazing a confusing array of cutlery laid out in place setting in front of her. Her confused face.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS VO
dialogues.text: Start on the outside... INT. DINING ROOM. HOUSE. DARTFORD. 1949. EVENING. DENIS whispers.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS VO
dialogues.text: .--and work your way in. A long table packed with silverware. She looks back at her ornate and rather hideous starter, a tiny wobbling savoury confection in aspic.  20

dialogues.speaker: PORTLY HOST
dialogues.text: ...-Attlee has his sights set on the steel industry, you mark my words.

dialogues.speaker: GREY SUITED MAN
dialogues.text: They’1l be nationalizing the bloody air next.

dialogues.speaker: MALE GUEST
dialogues.text: Yes, hold your breath, sir, that’s government property!

dialogues.speaker: PORTLY HOST
dialogues.text: So was your father a political man, too, Miss Roberts?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, to his core. And Mayor of Grantham.

dialogues.speaker: PORTLY HOST
dialogues.text: And a grocer as well!

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes. Ears prick up around the table. The Host is lost for something to say.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: And did you help, err, in the...shop?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. It was a family business.

dialogues.speaker: GREY SUITED MAN
dialogues.text: A very good starting point for the political life, I’m sure.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: That and a degree from Oxford. The put-down, though not intentional, causes Denis to smile. MARGARET catches the smile. She remains unruffled and goes back to her food, picking up a knife and fork, working her way in, teasing her hors d’oeuvres. INT. DINING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE.LONDON.PRESENT.EVENING. MARGARET sits oddly removed, hand instinctively covering her wine glass, as a WINE WAITER hovers.  21

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (hushed aside to

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Whisky. The MURMUR of conversation all around- INT. DINING ROOM. HOUSE. DARTFORD. 1949. EVENING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pudding is on the go and Margaret is warming to her theme.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: What I do think is that a man should be encouraged to stand on his own two feet. Yes we help people of course we help people. But for those that can do, they must just get up and do. And if something's wrong, they shouldn't just whine about it, they should get in there and DO something about it, change things. The female guests exchange glances. A half-chuckle from someone.

dialogues.speaker: PORTLY HOST
dialogues.text: With all due respect, Miss Roberts, what may have served in Grantham-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Can serve very well for the people of Dartford too.

dialogues.speaker: MALE GUEST
dialogues.text: Really? A general sense of quiet incredulity.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I know much more than those who have never lived on a limited income. Just like the man or woman on the street, when I am short one week, I have to make economies the next.

dialogues.speaker: GREY SUITED MAN
dialogues.text: Nothing like a slice of fiscal responsibility.  22

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: A man might call it fiscal responsibility, a woman might call it good housekeeping.

dialogues.speaker: MALE GUEST
dialogues.text: I’m not sure a home economics lesson is quite what the Dartford constituents need. They see industry being nationalized, the unions on the up, the pound on the slide...whoever can sort that lot out - he’s my man.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Or woman? Denis lets out a spontaneous guffaw as the host and hostess exchange looks. He signals ‘Get them out of here’. The men rise.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: Ladies shall we ?

dialogues.speaker: PORTLY HOST
dialogues.text: Miss Roberts, do join the ladies. The ladies scurry to the sitting room. Margaret is the last to leave. INT. SITTING ROOM. DARTFORD. 1949. EVENING. As Margaret closes the door to the dining room -

dialogues.speaker: PORTLY HOST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well. That’s told us! The men laugh raucously. She turns to the ladies who are regrouping at the fireplace and regarding her with suspicion. INT.DINING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. EVENING. The aftermath of the muted dinner party- MARGARET at the helm, a small whisky just visible nestled next to her wine glass. She is flushed and nicely mellow surrounded by mainly MALE GUESTS-

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: So, Margaret, how would you have dealt with this if you’d been Prime Minister?  23 MARGARET looks at him, her flicker of bemusement. .-.Slowly registering across the faces of her FRIENDS and COLLEAGUES including CAROL.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: The bombings, mummy. Today? MARGARET still lost

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We were just talking about them? MARGARET deflects, reaching for her glass, it trembles unsteady in her grasp.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: No, uhm, yes - we have always lived alongside evil. But it has never been so patient, so avid for carnage, so eager to carry innocents with it into oblivion.

dialogues.speaker: MALE GUEST
dialogues.text: So, would you -

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Western civilization must root out this evil, wherever it hides, or she risks defeat at the hands of global terror in a nuclear age. Unimaginable! Appreciative murmur of agreements amongst the listening party-

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: The Prime Minister gave a very good statement I thought.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes. Clever man. Quite a smoothie. Laughter- INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. NIGHT. MARGARET says final farewells to a guest. He walks away as another couple approach.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: You don’t mind if I sit down...  24 Sitting down on a nearby chair, MARGARET looks with feigned recollection at the FEMALE GUEST as she sinks down on the ground in front of her, gripping MARGARET’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE GUEST
dialogues.text: I heard you speak at conference in 1984 in Brighton just after the IRA bombed the Grand Hotel. You were remarkable. I hope you appreciate what an inspiration you have been for women like myself. MARGARET hesitates, smiles, nods to herself, considering-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: It used to be about trying to do something. Now its about trying to be someone. The FEMALE GUEST nods and scrambled to her feet, clearly concerned, shooting a look to her HUSBAND standing beside her, waiting to depart.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE GUEST
dialogues.text: Well anyway, I...thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Good night to you. MARGARET sits alone. In the background, the chatter of Carol saying final farewells.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Great to see you, thank you very much for coming.

dialogues.speaker: MALE GUEST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you. It was lovely, absolutely lovely. And I’m so pleased to see your mother looking so well. INT. DRESSING ROOM. HOUSE. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT.NIGHT. A mirror lined dressing room- CAROL helps MARGARET with her shoes.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: OK...hold on to me...that’s right. MARGARET struggles with the catch on her pearls  25

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Can you do the clasp, I can’t quite - CAROL hurries to help her, MARGARET quietly concedes. Fingers fumble to unclasp the pearls-—

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you. CAROL drops the pearls into a jewelry box, close to MARGARET, staring back at their reflections.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You’ve got an eyelash. CAROL catches the stray eyelash on the tip of her finger, holding it close to MARGARET, with a smile-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Make a wish. MARGARET, closes her eyes until- MARGARET blows. She opens them smiles. CAROL smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I spoke to Doctor Michael today- MARGARET glances away, deflecting.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He is very good and very expensive- MARGARET ignores her-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...I know you’re not due to see him for another month but I’ve spoken to him and he can fit you in tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just for a check up. (silence) Ma please-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: What does Mark think about it?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Mark?  26

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes. Tell him to come up. I want to talk to him about it. CAROL, hesitates, with concern-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Mark's with Sarah and the children. MARGARET nods, heading through into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Well tell him to come up and see me after he’s kissed them good night, would you Carol darling? INT. BEDROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. NIGHT. MARGARET, sitting on her bed, glances expectantly towards the door. Carol sits down beside her.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: He’s not here Mummy. MARGARET hesitates, CAROL using all her might, not to crumble under MARGARET’s cool gaze-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mark lives in South Africa... MARGARET inwardly flinches.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: «..you are not Prime Minister anymore and Dad is...Dad is dead- Silence-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: You look exhausted, dear. You really must try to get some sleep. Taxis'll be few and far between at this hour...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Righty-ho. Night night Ma. Sleep well.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Good night, dear. The slam of a door. MARGARET sits, alone.  27 INT. SADLERS WELLS. LONDON. 1950. NIGHT. MARGARET’S POV of Denis turning to her in the theatre. He smiles. MARGARET’s FINGERS absently grazing over the programme, in time with the music- SUDDENLY a closed fist reaches out, then opens to reveal a sugar mouse. Margaret’s fingers reach for it, but it’s teasingly withdrawn. Finally, she takes its. She turns to smile at DENIS, her face is glowing with happiness- INT. TOWN HALL 1950. NIGHT. MARGARET sits on the edge of a trestle table, scrunching a rosette in her hand. The Town Hall is empty save for a couple of Volunteers stacking chairs and sweeping the floor. The litter of election night is everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Twenty-four-year-old Miss Margaret Roberts lost her bid to win a seat in Parliament today, but she has put new life into the Dartford Conservative Association. Winning candidate Mr Dodds had better watch out, this bright young woman is on his tail. DENIS appears in the doorway, carrying fish and chips. He slides them down in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Eat! MARGARET almost smiles. Then sinks once more into misery.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Disaster.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Hang on...Hang on...Hang on... DENIS fishes in his pocket pulling out a hip flask. An impromptu supper made. MARGARET takes in the aftermath of rosettes, the whiff of defeat all around.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You shaved thousands off their majority. You did splendidly.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Not splendidly enough.  28

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Ah I see. Self pity. MARGARET eyes him, mid chip-

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No one is saying you don’t need a safe seat. You deserve a safe seat. But it does not come unless you learn to play the game a little.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: What game? She is fuming but he regroups with a big breath.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: You are a grocer’s daughter-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (fiercely) -And proud of being- He grabs her hand, silencing her.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: - in their eyes. A single grocer's daughter. But if you were to become the wife of a moderately successful businessman- For the first time, we see MARGARET taken by surprise.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’d get to parliament, and I'd get to be the happiest man in- in wherever they select you. (SILENCE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret, will you marry me? She is genuinely stunned.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well ? She is frozen. Then she begins to smile and nod her head and smile.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes! He leans over and kisses her, long and passionately until

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: What ?  29

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I love you so much but...I will never be one of those women Denis - who stays silent and pretty on the arm of her husband. Or remote and alone in the kitchen doing the washing up for that matter.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: (trying to retain the moment ) We'll get a help for that. He leans forward to kiss her again but she pulls away a little.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: No - one’s life must matter, Denis. Beyond the cooking and the cleaning and the children, one’s life must mean more than that - I cannot die washing up a tea cup. He sits up and stares as if seeing her for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean it Denis, say you understand.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: That’s why I want to marry you, my dear. She kisses him. A CHINK of a TEACUP- They pull apart. FLUSHED and GIGGLING on seeing- A LONE WOMAN enters the hall, cleaning up the last of the tea cups, and generally tidying.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now eat. MARGARET smiles her joy at him as ‘SHALL WE DANCE’ swells. And now she’s in his arms as they dance, swirling through the election debris, eyes only for each other.  30 INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. NIGHT. MARGARET now on all fours, struggling with her glasses. A pile of DVD's on the floor, The KING and I amongst them momentarily catching her eye until- A DVD with hand-written scrawl that we can’t quite read. MARGARET flicks open the box, struggling to get the DVD out. Fiddling with the DVD player, MARGARET puts in the disc and considers, squinting at the remote, trying to make the DVD player work until, suddenly... Super 8 footage - 1959 Children on a beach in wind-swept, grainy super 8. Denis with a golf club and ping pong balls practicing his drive from a tee, sending ball after ball skying into the sea. Mark and Carol charge into the water to retrieve them.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: There they are, my little twins. Mark... DENIS approaches the camera laughing and appears to take hold of it. MARGARET is seen sitting on a wobbly camping stool, hardly dressed for the beach, surrounded by papers weighed held down by pebbles. She merrily returns to her work.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Cornwall, wasn’t it? Bloody hell... Look at ‘em, little imps. You never really got golf, did you? DENIS sits behind her on the sofa in a dressing gown, watching the footage. She sips her whisky.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: You look happy.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Yes, I do, don’t I? You’re drinking too much. MARGARET ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whatcha doing? DENIS looks at MARGARET, unwavering. She resumes a search The Iron Lady - FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT - 8th April 11 (c) 31

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not like you. Looking back. MARGARET SUDDENLY presses rewind on the remote, clutched in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t want to dig around too deep, M. Don’t know what you might find. The rapid rewind of Denis swinging his golf club.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can rewind it, but you can’t change it. She freezes the image of him turning to camera, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: They grow up so fast. Margaret turns with something to say, but Denis doesn’t seem to be there anymore. INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT.NIGHT. Now on the screen, Mark on a swing. MARGARET'S face softens.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Mark. He turns and rushes towards the camera, whooshing past it. Without breaking step, suddenly, he’s in the room, running past Margaret, still cheering and whooping. MARGARET’s hand, just skimming MARK’s golden curls. As he moves on, MARGARET’s curiosity caught following him out and down the corridor of Chester Square, seeing the Mark and Carol disappear round a corner. INT. HALLWAY. HOUSE. FARNBOROUGH. KENT. 1959. DAWN. The view beyond-

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER VO
dialogues.text: Mr Eric Deakins, Labour... 13,437... The CRUNCH of gravel as CAROL and MARK race across the drive towards a blue ford car, covered with Tory blue streamers and a VOTE FOR THATCHER poster scrawled with the words Victory.  30 INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. NIGHT. MARGARET now on all fours, struggling with her glasses. A pile of DVD's on the floor, The KING and I amongst them momentarily catching her eye until- A DVD with hand-written scrawl that we can’t quite read. MARGARET flicks open the box, struggling to get the DVD out. Fiddling with the DVD player, MARGARET puts in the disc and considers, squinting at the remote, trying to make the DVD player work until, suddenly... Super 8 footage - 1959 Children on a beach in wind-swept, grainy super 8. Denis with a golf club and ping pong balls practicing his drive from a tee, sending ball after ball skying into the sea. Mark and Carol charge into the water to retrieve them.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: There they are, my little twins. Mark... DENIS approaches the camera laughing and appears to take hold of it. MARGARET is seen sitting on a wobbly camping stool, hardly dressed for the beach, surrounded by papers weighed held down by pebbles. She merrily returns to her work.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Cornwall, wasn’t it? Bloody hell... Look at ‘em, little imps. You never really got golf, did you? DENIS sits behind her on the sofa in a dressing gown, watching the footage. She sips her whisky.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: You look happy.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Yes, I do, don’t I? You’re drinking too much. MARGARET ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whatcha doing? DENIS looks at MARGARET, unwavering. She resumes a search  33 MARGARET fingers brush dark panelled walls, making her way along endless corridors. Gothic arches, venerable busts, wood panelling and stone. MARGARET’s pov as she stays to the side of the impressive corridor. She passes men in suits and groups. Others come towards her and notice her. Her POV as she pushes open a first door ‘TEA ROOM’ - a circle of men turn round in chorus as if something with three heads has appeared. POV of a second opening door marked MEMBERS. A row of urinals. Two headless bodies come towards the camera, scrambling to zip up their flies. POV of the promise of sanctuary. LADY MEMBERS. The door opens onto a cupboard sized space. An ironing board. A sea of men’s Oxford shoes from ground level. A pair of woman’s shoes appear amongst them. They go on tip toe. From above we see Margaret’s hat amongst the sea of mens heads and shoulders. Margaret is carried along in the sea of MALE MP’s OXFORD SHOES. AIREY NEAVE [Extremely dapper, friendly 43] approaches MARGARET.

dialogues.speaker: AIREY NEAVE
dialogues.text: Mrs Thatcher ! Airey Neave. Welcome to the madhouse. Follow me. The doors swing open-

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOUSE OF COMMONS CHAMBER. 1974. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET, now SECRETARY OF STATE FOR EDUCATION, on the front bench, wearing a neat blue suit and a hat, a phalanx of MINISTERS sitting beside and around her, BLUE and GREY SUITED MEN, almost at first glance indistinguishable, with PRIME MINISTER EDWARD HEATH (late 50's), neat, effete, slumped rather forlornly on the bench. MARGARET, her speech and papers in her hand is fighting hard but the OPPOSITION LABOUR BENCHES scent blood - and they literally bray, getting to their feet and shaking their order papers in her face. The SPEAKER tries to control the chamber but his VOICE is almost lost in the bedlam.  34

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER
dialogues.text: The Right Honourable Lady the Secretary of State for Education.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: The right honourable gentleman knows that we have no choice but to shut down the schools! Cries of ‘Shame!’ From the opposition. The chamber reduced to a bear-pit. HEATH glum and offering no help to MARGARET whose voice becomes increasingly shrill.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because his union paymasters have called a strike deliberately to cripple our economy. Teachers cannot teach when there is no heating, no lighting in their classrooms. And I ask the honourable gentleman, whose fault is that?

dialogues.speaker: SHADOW MINISTER
dialogues.text: Methinks the Right Honourable lady doth screech to much. If she wants us to take her seriously she must learn to calm down! The OPPOSITION BENCHES love that, rocking in their seats, laughing... falsely of course. But MARGARET is aware that there are many MEN behind her, on the government benches, who are also sniggering in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: If the right honorable gentleman could perhaps attend more closely to WHAT I am saying, rather than HOW I am saying it, he may receive a valuable education in spite of himself! Her opposite number Shadow Minister looks almost smug: smiling, pointing a finger at her.

dialogues.speaker: SHADOW MINISTER
dialogues.text: Why has this Conservative government failed? Why has it forced so many in the public sector into taking strike action to save their own jobs? It brings the OPPOSITION benches to their feet, shouting, applauding, stamping...  35

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WESTMINSTER STREET. 1974. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET walking with AIREY NEAVE towards Downing Street for a Cabinet Meeting. All around, heaped high on either side as far as the eye can see are bags of rubbish. But not neatly stacked, just thrown there, many of them rotting down, spilling their filthy, putrid contents onto the street.

dialogues.speaker: SHADOW MINISTER VO
dialogues.text: Minister, the breakdown of essential public services - transport, electricity, sanitation is not the fault of the trades unions but of this Conservative government in which you so shamefully serve! The stench is awful - and MARGARET’S expression reflects that as she picks her way through. INT. CABINET ROOM. DOWNING STREET. 1974. NIGHT. The ranks of BESPECTACLED GREY-SUITED MINISTERS at the Cabinet table, including GEOFFREY HOWE.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: So these power cuts will continue unless we can reach a compromise. EDWARD HEATH is in mid-flow.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The miners are asking for a 35% increase in wages. Obviously we can’t go anywhere near that. The unions are not our enemies and never have been. We want - and have always wanted - the broadest consensus... The MINISTERS nod. MARGARET determinedly edges a little forward so that she is in equal line with the other MALE MINISTERS.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sure we are all in agreement that we must do nothing for the moment that will further inflame the current situation.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER 1
dialogues.text: Hear hear, Prime Minister.  36 MARGARET leans forward for a better view, trying to catch his eye. HEATH wavers, mid-speech. All turn to look at MARGARET - who sits unwavering. HEATH resumes.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: - the fact of the matter is, it’s absolutely crucial that we are seen by the public to be acting as conciliators and not aggressors. (Finally acknowledging Margaret) Yes, Education Secretary.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes... All eyes TURN on her again, hearing the reservation in her voice.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Prime Minister, with the Miners’ leader calling today for the army to mutiny in support of the strikes, this seems the wrong time for conciliation. SUDDENLY ALL THE LIGHTS GO OUT. A lot of ‘bloody hell’ ‘oh for god's sake’.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH
dialogues.text: Be patient. They’1l come back on in a minute. A beam of light cuts through, just for an instant picking out HEATH'S moon-like face surrounded by darkness. MARGARET holds the small torch.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you, Margaret. A snigger, then the lights flicker back on.

dialogues.speaker: HEATH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your thoughts are duly noted. MARGARET turns of the torch and clicks her handbag shut in satisfaction. Heath’s words echo in her head, ‘compromise...compromise...compromise...’ An inward look as she’s caught by a memory.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We on this island are strong. We’re self-reliant. Napoleon called us a nation of shopkeepers.  37 INT. TOWN HALL. 1949. NIGHT. The packed town hall, ALFRED ROBERTS in full flow on stage.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED
dialogues.text: He meant it as an insult but to me it’s a compliment. That’s why he couldn’t beat us, and that’s why Hitler can’t beat us. The crowd of men applaud. The lone woman in their midst, YOUNG MARGARET watches her father, face aglow.

dialogues.speaker: ALFRED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We Conservatives believe in giving people the freedom and opportunity to fulfil their own potential, especially the young. There’s no good in pretending we’re all equal, we’re not all the same, never have been, never will be. We should encourage our children to aspire to achieve more than we have, for our children today will be the leaders of tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR. STREET. CENTRAL LONDON. 1974. DAWN
dialogues.text: .+.CAROL and MARGARET seated, driving steadily along a deserted street. MARGARET thoughtful as the radio plays.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE ON THE RADIO
dialogues.text: It’s 1974 and you’d think it was WWII. Blackouts, no petrol. It’s a mess. Heath should resign now and make way for someone who’s not afraid to tackle the unions. CAROL'S nervous prattle begins to break through.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I swear, it’s all gone completely out of my head. My driving instructor thinks I should pass but I feel as if I’ve hardly had any lessons. Ridiculous isn’t it? Maybe third time lucky.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Right. The only thing you should remember is that everyone else is either reckless or inept. And often both. MARGARET eyes the road, gesturing CAROL to move forward.  38

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One must be brave if one is to take the wheel-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Right-o.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Move over... Move to your right a little bit...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: But if I move to the right aren't I on the wrong side of the road?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Carol!

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Well he’s in the way!

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: To the right. Move to the right! A yelp from CAROL as the car swerves a little, narrowly missing a lone CYCLIST-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So sorry! Terribly sorry! MARGARET throws a wave from the wound down window. The CYCLIST swerves on recognizing her, watching as the car goes round and round the square, almost balletic.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hey, look at me, driving! CAROL’s squeals of delight, let loose on the open road. The tyres screech on the corner. INT. KITCHEN. FLOOD STREET. LONDON. 1974. DAWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter - VOICES on the approach-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Thanks Ma, that was terrific! I really feel I’ve got a handle on it now. CAROL and MARGARET entering kitchen, still giddy from their adventure.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You should have seen us, Pa.  39 DENIS in his dressing gown burning toast and attempting to make breakfast -

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Have you been trying to make breakfast? For Goodness sake, Denis! DENIS scrapes down the toast, eggs boiling in the pan.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: I can boil a bloody egg.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Mummy took me for a test drive - We went absolutely everywhere. All over the place -

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (sudden/cutting in) I’ve decided. I’m going to run. MARGARET smiles, a growing resolution gripping her.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I’m going to run for Leader of the Party. CAROL'S utter disappointment on seeing she has lost MARGARET already.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Silly me! CAROL storms out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: (calling after) Good luck!

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: All the time I thought I was having a driving lesson, it was all about my mother, just for a change!

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: What’s she on about?

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: It's her driving test this morning!  40

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Oh, right. Of course. A BEAT.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Are you saying you want to be Prime Minister?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (with false patience) What I’m saying is that someone must force the point, say the unsayable. None of these men have the guts. MARGARET sees the burnt toast and energetically starts clearing up and putting more bread under the grill.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: The Prime Minister has been very loyal to you, MT. He tries, with a trembling hand, to scoop boiled eggs from the pan.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: But he’s weak, and he’s weakened the party. One must know when to go. (glancing at him) You're shaking. She reaches out.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: I can do it! DENIS pulls his arm away, sending boiled eggs flying. SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Goodness me! What is the matter with everyone this morning? A beat. He looks utterly fragile.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: I’ve told you what the matter is. The business is a bit rocky at the moment and the Doctor thinks I need a rest.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: And do you need a rest?  41 It’s almost challenging. He doesn’t answer and she doesn’t notice.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We both know that it’s highly unlikely that I would ever be elected leader, I’1l never be elected leader. But I will run. I will run. Just to nip at their heels and make them reaffirm the principles on which the Conservative Party must stand. There’s so much to do. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) You're insufferable, Margaret, do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Denis, you married someone who is committed to public service, you knew that. And it is my duty -

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Don’t call it duty. It’s ambition which has got you this far. Ambition. And the rest of us, me, the children, we can all go to hell! The SLAM of the door, DENIS gone-

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don’t worry about me, I'll be fine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET and DENIS sit on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Where did you go?

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: South Africa.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes.  42

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN. FLOOD STREET. LONDON. 1974. DAWN
dialogues.text: MARGARET eats breakfast alone, engrossed in the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: How many days passed before you realized I was gone? Probably had to ask the cleaning woman where I was.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SITTING ROOM. CHESTER SQ. PRESENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: MARGARET grips her whiskey, shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: When did I lose track of everyone?

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Too busy climbing the greasy pole MT. Cutting in -

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mrs Thatcher I understand you recently visited the United States of America. MARGARET’S attention is caught by an old interview, playing on the TV. She leans forward. On screen, she sits in a neat hat, leaning forward eagerly.

dialogues.speaker: INTERVIEWER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What was it you took away from that visit which may be of value here in Great Britain?

dialogues.speaker: INT. STUDIO. LONDON. 1975. NIGHT
dialogues.text: MARGARET perched on a chair, smiling at the TV

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Oh that’s rather easy to answer, actually. They are unafraid of success. INT. REECE’S OFFICE. LONDON. 1975. DAY MARGARET is watching the same interview on a TV monitor. She is watching herself intently, as are REECE and AIREY NEAVE. They are polar opposites, REECE flamboyant to NEAVE’s bluff.  43 She sounds very plummy, like a Conservative party wife from the shires. And she wears a hat.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET ON TELEVISION
dialogues.text: We in Great Britain and in Europe are formed mainly by our history. They on the other hand are formed by their philosophy. Not by what has been, but by what can be. Oh, we have a great deal that we can learn from them, yes. Oh yes! MARGARET is trapped in the moment - but the two men exchange a glance. NEAVE freezes the picture. MARGARET smiles uneasily, like someone expecting a compliment. REECE considers her, long and hard. It is a little unsettling until-

dialogues.speaker: REECE
dialogues.text: Well er...For a start, that hat has got to go. And the pearls. In fact I think all hats may have to go. You look and sound like a privileged Conservative wife and we've already got her vote. You’ve got lovely hair but we need to do something with it - to make it more-

dialogues.speaker: AIREY NEAVE
dialogues.text: Important.

dialogues.speaker: REECE
dialogues.text: Yes. Give it more impact. But the main thing is your voice. Its too high. It has no authority.

dialogues.speaker: AIREY NEAVE
dialogues.text: Methinks the Lady doth screech too much

dialogues.speaker: REECE
dialogues.text: People don’t want to be harangued by a woman or hectored. Persuaded yes. That ‘oh yes’ at the end of the interview, that’s authoritative, that’s the voice of a leader. MARGARET stares at him.  44

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: It’s all very well to talk about changing my voice, Mr Reece, but for some of my colleagues to imagine me as their leader would be like imagining, I don’t know, being led into battle by their chambermaid. It’s my background, and my sex. No matter how I’ve tried, and I have tried, to fit in, I will never be truly one of them. Both REECE and NEAVE are aware that she has spoken very nakedly - and is thus extremely vulnerable.

dialogues.speaker: REECE
dialogues.text: If I may say so - I think that’s your trump card. You’re flying in the face of everything the Tories have been thus far. It’s really very exciting. One simply has to maximise your appeal, bring out all your qualities and make you look, and sound, like the leader that you could be.

dialogues.speaker: NEAVE
dialogues.text: You’ve got it in you to go the whole distance.

dialogues.speaker: REECE
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Prime Minister?! Oh no. Oh no no no. In Britain? There will be no female Prime Minister here, not in my lifetime. No. And I told Airey, I don’t expect to win the leadership, but I am going to run. Just to shake up the party. NEAVE moves in intently-

dialogues.speaker: NEAVE
dialogues.text: Respectfully, Margaret, I disagree. If you want to change this party, lead it. If you want to change the country, lead it. What we're talking about here today is surface. What’s crucial is that you hold your course, and stay true to who you are. Never be anything other than yourself. MARGARET, though flattered, looks sceptical.  45

dialogues.speaker: REECE
dialogues.text: Leave us to do the rest.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I am in your hands. I may be persuaded to surrender the hat. But the pearls were a gift from my husband on the birth of our twins and they are absolutely non-negotiable. MARGARET smiles at them.

dialogues.speaker: INT. REHEARSAL ROOM. NATIONAL THEATRE. LONDON. 1975. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET stands humming, a THEATRICAL COACH presses her hand to MARGARET’S stomach.

dialogues.speaker: THEATRICAL VOICE COACH
dialogues.text: And...bring it down. MARGARET hums lower, tries to project her voice.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Maaaaaaaaaaaa.

dialogues.speaker: THEATRICAL VOICE COACH
dialogues.text: Good, I think we can loose the handbag, Mrs Thatcher...Hands down the sides...Because this isn’t really about the voice, it’s about belief...A nice deep breath. REECE and NEAVE are watching and monitoring the performance. DENIS, though present, is having a crafty fag by the window.

dialogues.speaker: THEATRICAL VOICE COACH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you're calling Mr Thatcher, how would you do that? MARGARET looks over at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (calls) Denis. He doesn’t react.

dialogues.speaker: THEATRICAL VOICE COACH
dialogues.text: Yes, I want more authority, I want conviction, I want -—  46

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (a little more authority) Denis.

dialogues.speaker: THEATRICAL VOICE COACH
dialogues.text: That's right, one more time, deep breath - She puts on her new, lower voice.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Denis. And DENIS reacts immediately, like a guilty thing surprised, stabbing out his cigarette, turning quickly towards her.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Yes MT! EXT. YARD. ICE CREAM FACTORY. DAY. MARGARET makes her way through a crowd of applauding workers in crisp white uniforms. Like them, she wears a white cap on her head.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: You are the backbone of our nation! Small firms like Loveday’s Ice Cream. How are you? So nice to meet you ladies. General merriment as MARGARET, now inside an ice-cream van, has a go at dispensing an ice cream from the machine.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’‘1l just have a small one, because I’m watching my figure. (handing the cone out) That’s for you young man!

dialogues.speaker: INT. HAIR SALON. LONDON. 1975. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET is having new hair colour and the colourist is 75 percent through putting her hair in foil.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I passionately believe it’s the growth of small businesses into larger ones that is critical for Britain’s future.  47 REECE and NEAVE are sitting nearby, both of them reading the Financial Times. EXT. YARD. ICE CREAM FACTORY. DAY. MARGARET among the ladies again.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: It has to be something icy on a stick for Denis. Laughter.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (returning to her subject) That’s the only way we will produce jobs, real jobs, jobs that sustain.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HAIR SALON. LONDON. 1975. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET sitting under the dryer, cooking her new hair, still correcting paperwork while REECE and NEAVE look on, twiddling their thumbs.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FACTORY. LONDON. 1975. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET is standing on an impromptu stage outside a factory. She has a hard hat on her head.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: The Trade Union Movement was founded to protect workers. Now it persecutes them. It stops them from working. It is killing jobs and it is bringing this country to its knees. I say enough. It’s time to get up. It’s time to go to work. It’s time to put the Great back into Great Britain!

dialogues.speaker: INT. HAIR SALON. 1975. DAY
dialogues.text: The bouffant is now apparent. REECE AND NEAVE watch in awe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A darkened backstage. MARGARET, clutching her speech, goes over her lines. A FEMALE AIDE sprays her hair. She looks up, starts to move towards the light.  48 AIREY NEAVE is suddenly next to her.

dialogues.speaker: NEAVE
dialogues.text: Give ‘em hell! He looks her up and down, with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: NEAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You look magnificent. Next stop Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Oh Airey... As from the stage -

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: The leader of the Conservative Party, Margaret Thatcher! MARGARET pushes back her shoulders and walks into battle to the sound of GROWING APPLAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRITAIN NEEDS THE CONSERVATIVES bannered overhead and hung with Union Jacks. MARGARET a swathe of blue, as she passes through her GREY SUITED CABINET. From behind she stands, arms outstretched, accepting the applause, a shock of bright blonde hair as she stands before a sea of CONSERVATIVE DELEGATES holding up letter cards WE LOVE YOU MAGGIE! Wedges of fanatical party faithful on their feet ina kind of rapture. The blessed Margaret ! DENIS just visible with REECE, HOWE, PYM, HESELTINE and several other GREY SUITED MINISTERS of her cabinet, seated close behind now jumping to their feet, with obvious relief and delight -

dialogues.speaker: RAPTUROUS APPLAUSE, FLASH BULBS POPPING
dialogues.text: MARGARET smiles, glorious, catching DENIS’ eye. He is brimming with pride. AIREY NEAVE beams at his protegee. INT. CORRIDOR. HOUSE. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on a photograph of MARGARET and AIREY NEAVE. MARGARET sits looking at it, her coat on, her handbag on her lap.  49 INT. UNDERGROUND CAR PARK. HOUSE OF COMMONS. 1979. EVE. MARGARET is loading papers and files into the boot of her car. AIREY NEAVE drives towards her, winding down his window.

dialogues.speaker: NEAVE
dialogues.text: Good night Margaret. My money’s on the filly to win!

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks Airey. Goodnight. He laughs and drives towards the exit of the car park. As MARGARET closes the boot and opens the door to get in the car suddenly there’s a MASSIVE EXPLOSION, the sound magnified by being in the cavernous underground. For a few seconds we don’t know what’s happened. Through the smoke we see MARGARET running up the ramp towards us.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. No, no! Airey! Her POV of the fireball of Neave’s car. As Margaret looks in horror at the scene. Her shattered face. NEWS V.O. The Irish National Liberation Army has claimed responsibility for the death of Airey Neave, Margaret Thatcher’s spokesman on Northern Ireland. INT. CONFERENCE HALL. NIGHT. MARGARET on the conference podium, blinking back tears. Behind her, Denis’ face etched with the same sorrow.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STEPS. HOUSE OF COMMONS. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET walks alone down the grand stairway, sombre, deep in thought. INT. CORRIDOR. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. DAY. MARGARET looks up from the photograph, tears in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: AIREY NEAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If you want to change the party, lead it. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: AIREY NEAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If you want to change the country, lead it. You’ve got it in you to go the whole distance! On MARGARET as memories flood in. A TV headline announces: ELECTION 1979.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CONFERENCE HALL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: MARGARET on the podium.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Now, as the test draws near, I ask your help. That together we can shake off the shackles of socialism and restore to greatness this country that we love so much. And the only way is for the Conservative Party to win! The black streak of MARGARET’S car, a blur of colour, faces, waving flags - TV footage of polling night. Swingometers, pollsters, impressionistic snatches of reported speech. More footage of PEOPLE coming out of polling stations. Jubilant crowds applauding... MARGARET, silhouetted in her iconic stance, arms aloft... INT. CAR. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1979. DAY. MARGARET peering out of the window, hands sunk in the lap, a flash of the Royal blue fabric of her skirt, clenched in fingers.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS READER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It's Friday the 4th of May, an historic day for Britain, a Conservative government led by Mrs. Thatcher is set to lead -

dialogues.speaker: NEWS READER 2, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mrs Ghandi in India, but never in the West has there been a woman Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: NEW READER 3, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The place that she has secured in British history, as the first woman ever to be invited to form a government. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: NEW READER 3, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The bonus of one of the most famous addresses in the world, Number 10 Downing Street. NOISE. FLAGS. BANNERS read ‘We LOVE YOU MAGGIE’ blur through the window, an abstract cacophony of noise and colour-

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: This is it, steady the buffs old girl. He clasps her hand for a moment as MARGARET smiles at him. The door swings open- EXT. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1979. DAY. The CAMERA from behind on MARGARET rising up out of the car, to face a waiting PRESS CORP. The jostle of a POLICE OFFICER, DENIS and OTHERS press her either side-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I should just like to say that I take very seriously the trust the British people placed in me today, and I will work hard every day to live up to that responsibility. And now, I should like to share with you a prayer of St Francis of Assisi: Where there is discord may we bring harmony... Where there is error may we bring truth... Where there is doubt may we bring faith... Where there is despair may we bring hope.. The CAMERA rises up, high above MARGARET until she is just a blue dot, on the dark tarmac, a lone woman standing facing the circle of cameras and microphones. The door of Number 10 looms ahead. INT. DRAWING ROOM. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1979. DAY. The cheers go over .. The CABINET gathering for a group shot-—

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Shoulders back, tummies in! Laughter. Michael Heseltine, standing behind MARGARET, reaches out to smooth a stray lock of her hair.  52

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh. Thank you, Michael. MARGARET seated at the heart of her entire CABINET, as if she is royalty. The FLASH of the CAMERA - the image frozen. INT. CORRIDOR. HOUSE. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. DAY. The same image, framed on a side table beside MARGARET. The distant hum of a hoover.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I’m perfectly healthy. There’s no need for any of this. Denis appears, his hand inside his shoe, polishing it vigorously.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Just let them look under the bonnet, MT. Check everything is hunky dory. MARGARET hesitates. She sits in silence until-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Really it’s becoming quite tiresome.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: You. (beat) I was on my own for twenty four years before I met you and I can Manage perfectly well without you now. So will you please go away and stop bothering me.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CONSULTING ROOM. HARLEY STREET. LONDON. PRESENT.DAY
dialogues.text: A distinguished consulting room- MARGARET sits silent, as an EMINENT DOCTOR checks her blood pressure. The beep of the machine, steady and monotonous until-

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Just look straight at me, straight ahead, that’s it.  53 The DOCTOR scribbles some notes, considering-

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you noticing night sweats?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: No

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Hallucinations? MARGARET hesitates. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Sleep?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes, I sleep. Four, five hours a night.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: So you wake early?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: And I stay up late. I always have. She looks at him as if he really should know this about her. The DOCTOR notes this down.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: We just want to keep abreast of it.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Grief is a very natural state.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: My husband has been gone for years. Cancer.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Carol says you've decided to let his things go. Probably a good thing.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes. It was my idea. To Oxfam. Perfectly good stuff. People can use these things.  54

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Still it must be a bit disorientating. You are bound to be feeling.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: What? What am I ‘bound to be feeling’? The DOCTOR looks up from his note taking, hearing the quiet challenge in MARGARET’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: People don’t ‘think’ any more. They ‘feel’. ‘How are you feeling?’ ‘Oh I don’t feel comfortable with that’ ‘Oh, I’m so sorry but we, the group were feeling...’ D’you know, one of the great problems of our age is that we are governed by people who care more about feelings than thoughts and ideas. (beat) Now thoughts and ideas. That interests me. (beat) Ask me what I am thinking- The DOCTOR hesitates, letting MARGARET settle until-

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: What are you thinking, Margaret? MARGARET looks at the DOCTOR, quietly struggling with a fury, threatening to unleash-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Watch your thoughts, for they become words. Watch your words, for they become actions. Watch your actions, for they become habits. Watch your habits, for they become your character. And watch your character, for it becomes your destiny. What we think, we become. My father always said that. (beat) And I think I am fine. (beat) But I do so appreciate your kind concern. The sudden and persistent buzz of an intercom-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, do please answer that.  55 MARGARET holds his gaze, with quiet unwavering steel unsettling the DOCTOR a little.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It might be someone who needs you. The DOCTOR reluctantly answers his intercom- INT. CORRIDOR CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. DUSK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUNE heads up the stairs, MARGARET following behind.

dialogues.speaker: JUNE
dialogues.text: I’'ll give Carol a quick ring, let her know we’re back, then I’11l put your electric blanket on. MARGARET nods. Looking through the bannisters, her eyes fall on- A golf ball running along the floor. MARGARET considers, looks up-

dialogues.speaker: DENNIS OOV
dialogues.text: Steady, steady, steady! Damn. Fore! The ball bounces down the wooden stairs. INT. KITCHEN. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DUSK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET opens the fridge. A cold plated lunch resting on a shelf.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: What about that medicine man, eh? Ah. Cold supper. Standards are slipping Margaret. MARGARET ignores DENIS taking out the plate unwrapping the cellophane off it and placing it on a table, already laid ready for her to eat.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well you really gave it to that quack didn’t you, darling ? Just like the old days! Hallucinations my eye! DENIS picks up a piece of cucumber from her plate. She absently smacks at his hand.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How dare he? DENIS smiles.  56

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But then you give us all the run around, don’t you? MARGARET looks at him, silently infuriated. INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. DUSK. MARGARET pours herself a whiskey. DENIS looms close, serves a splash of soda.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: I know you can hear me, sweetheart, so there’s no use pretending you can’t. MARGARET turns, ignoring him.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Enough. Denis, enough!

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: (saluting) Dismissed! INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. DUSK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET sits reading DENIS’ spy novel.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: She does it in the end. Kills him- MARGARET slams the book closed.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t know why you’re being so scratchy. MARGARET’s eyes dart to the clock.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s not as if you've got anyone else to talk to. Shaking her head, MARGARET tries to block him out.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When the Himalayan peasant meets the he-bear in his pride -  57

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: You know, it’s a marvel to me that you can still quote huge chunks of Kipling but try remembering the name of that woman who’s just made you that godawful cold collation... No? Come on... you can do it... month of the year... one syllable... rhymes with moon

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (sudden/like a lightbulb) June. MARGARET turns to DENIS, a quiet appalling victory.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: June! Bingo.
