Knew you'd get there in the end. “When the Himalayan peasant meets the he-bear in his pride, He shouts to scare the monster, who will often turn aside, but the she-bear thus accosted rends the peasant tooth and nail. For the female of the species is more deadly than the male...” As he continues, MARGARET reaches for the remote, turns the television on. She moves onto the radio. Then the stereo. She moves on, talking to herself- A gradual growing cacophony of sound- INT. KITCHEN. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. DUSK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET flicks on mixers, radios, toasters- INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. DUSK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The noise almost unbearable now- MARGARET turns on a hi-fi, the TV now on-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: If I can’t hear you then I can’t see you. And if I can’t see you then you are not here. MARGARET closes her eyes.  58

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And if you are not here, I am not going mad. I will not...I will not go mad. She opens them and suddenly freezes on seeing an image of herself, bewildered and leaving Harley Street, caught on the TV-

dialogues.speaker: BBC VOICEOVER
dialogues.text: Baroness Thatcher made an apparently routine visit to her doctor today. Although rarely seen in public, Lady Thatcher, the longest serving Prime Minister of the twentieth century, remains a controversial figure. MARGARET turns up the volume to full, trying to hear over the cacophony of noise the changing images on the TV illuminating her pale face.

dialogues.speaker: JUNE
dialogues.text: Margaret-— MARGARET barely sees her, eyes riveted to the TV.

dialogues.speaker: BBC VOICE OVER
dialogues.text: Almost lovingly dubbed by the Soviets The Iron Lady, she’s also credited, with her friend Ronald Reagan, with a decisive role in the ending of the Cold War. Her supporters claim she transformed the British economy and reversed the country’s post-war decline. Her detractors blame her savage public spending cuts and sweeping privatization of - JUNE moves like a dervish through the house, muting the television and turning off the last of the appliances- A gradual silence descends until- MARGARET takes in the image of herself on the mute screen, standing bewildered on the steps of Harley Street.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (almost to self) I don’t recognize myself.  59 INT. BATHROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. NIGHT. The shelf of a bathroom cabinet. Shaving brush. Razor. Medicaments. MARGARET begins to pull them all off the shelves.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Am I out of the doghouse yet? Then a pair of glasses. More gently, MARGARET’S hand reaches into the cupboard and takes the glasses in her hand. INT. BEDROOM. HOUSE.CHESTER SQUARE.PRESENT.NIGHT. MARGARET lies in bed, book in her lap, DENIS beside her reading the paper. She closes the book and pulls off her reading glasses.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: They’re unveiling that portrait of me at Number 10 next month. The invitation’s on the mantelpiece. So there'll be Churchill, Lloyd George and me. Just the three of us.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I said I didn’t want any big fuss but they insisted..

dialogues.speaker: SILENCE-
dialogues.text: Lovely little article in The Telegraph... The Woman Who Changed the Face of History..

dialogues.speaker: SILENCE-
dialogues.text: Voices from the past intrude -—

dialogues.speaker: FOOT VO
dialogues.text: Less than two years ago, the Prime Minister quoted St. Francis and talked about bringing faith, hope and harmony to this country. MARGARET suddenly reaches out a hand, her hand shaking-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Denis? She turns in bed. Sudden panic, DENIS is gone-  60

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HECKLING chamber as MARGARET sits, facing LABOUR OUTRAGE, the labour leader, FOOT, grips his paper, mid speech-

dialogues.speaker: FOOT
dialogues.text: Can the Right Honourable Lady deny, that having brought about the highest level of unemployment since 1934- MARGARET bides her time on the front bench, waiting her turn, surrounded by her CABINET MINISTERS including HOWE, PYM and HESELTINE-

dialogues.speaker: FOOT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The biggest fall in total output in steel and coal production in one year since 1931. And the biggest collapse in industrial production since 1921. MARGARET remains seemingly calm and serene, and yet one hand quietly grips the bench, her wedding ring tapping against the wood nervously.

dialogues.speaker: FOOT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can she also accept that her free market economics designed to create a growing middle class ensures that the rich get richer and the poor are irrelevant!

dialogues.speaker: INT. CAR. STREETS. LONDON. 1980. DAY
dialogues.text: A rising roar of voices -

dialogues.speaker: PROTESTORS
dialogues.text: Maggie Maggie Maggie! Out Out Out! Maggie Maggie Maggie! Out Out Out! MARGARET in her car driving through the blur of furious PROTESTORS.

dialogues.speaker: PROTESTOR 1
dialogues.text: You’re supposed to be a mother! You’re not a mother, you’re s monster! You’re a monster!  61 INT. DRAWING ROOM. DOWNING STREET. 1980. EVENING. CLOSE UP on a button - The STEADY IN and OUT of a needle pulling taut on a thread. MARGARET stands, swathed in a glittering long dinner dress, a SEAMSTRESS stitching a stray button on the front of the bodice on her dress. Geoffrey Howe stands nearby in a dinner jacket.

dialogues.speaker: HESELTINE
dialogues.text: May we have a word, Prime Minister? A bank of MINISTERS, including HESELTINE, PYM, PRIOR, HOWE and GILMOUR, gather before her.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes, but in order to arrive at the palace on time, Geoffrey and I are will be walking out of that door in 15 minutes. As you can see -

dialogues.speaker: HESELTINE
dialogues.text: I know you’re running late Margaret, but we have to address this situation in light of tomorrow’s blistering press coverage. Blistering! The knives are out. Your draft budget’s been leaked, Geoffrey, they are baying for our blood!

dialogues.speaker: HOWE
dialogues.text: Michael we can’t possibly buckle at the first sign of difficulty. The SCRATCH of PRIOR’s hand on unkempt hair-

dialogues.speaker: HESELTINE
dialogues.text: No one is saying we have to buckle.

dialogues.speaker: PRIOR
dialogues.text: But is this really the time to make these spending cuts in the middle of one of the deepest recessions this country has ever experienced?

dialogues.speaker: HESTLETINE
dialogues.text: We need a plan of action, Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: PYM
dialogues.text: Absolutely. A strategy.  62

dialogues.speaker: GILMOUR
dialogues.text: We must be armed.

dialogues.speaker: PRIOR
dialogues.text: Agreed. MARGARET stiffens, the needle momentarily hovering mid stitch as MARGARET shifts a little- The SEAMSTRESS resumes sewing-

dialogues.speaker: PRIOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s a perception, Margaret rightly or wrongly, that we are now completely out of touch with the country. The patronizing tone inflames her.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Really. (beat) How much is a pack of Lurpak?

dialogues.speaker: PYM
dialogues.text: Lurpak?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Butter, Francis. (silence) Forty two pence. Anchor butter is forty pence. Flora margarine, still the cheapest, is thirty eight pence. I can assure you I am not out of touch. Another MINISTER - GILMOUR - whispers the words: “Grocer’s Daughter” - as a put down. The men smirk. MARGARET has caught the moment. A sudden flash of the pretty girls in the Grantham Street long ago, laughing at her.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What - did you say? GILMOUR makes a gesture.

dialogues.speaker: GILMOUR
dialogues.text: Nothing. Nothing, Prime Minister. MARGARET is furious.  63

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Don’t try to hide you opinions. Goodness me, I’d much rather you were honest and straightforward about them - instead of continuously and damagingly leaking them to the press. Well?

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTARILY SILENT-
dialogues.text: MARGARET’s eyes travel around the room in waiting-

dialogues.speaker: PYM
dialogues.text: Well, people can’t pay their mortgages.

dialogues.speaker: GILMOUR
dialogues.text: The manufacturing industry is practically on its knees.

dialogues.speaker: PYM
dialogues.text: Honest, hard-working, decent people are losing their homes. It's terribly shameful.

dialogues.speaker: GILMOUR
dialogues.text: The point is, Prime Minister, that we must moderate the pace -—

dialogues.speaker: HESELTINE
dialogues.text: - if we’re even to have a hope of winning the next election-

dialogues.speaker: PYM
dialogues.text: Quite right.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Ah. Worried about our careers, are we? They make noises - to the effect that nothing could be further from the truth. But MARGARET has their measure.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, if we don’t cut spending we will be bankrupt. Yes the medicine is harsh but the patient requires it in order to live. Shall we withhold the medicine? No! We are not wrong. We did not seek election and win in order to manage the decline of a great nation. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The people of this country chose us because they believe we can restore the health of the British economy and we will do just that! Barring a failure of nerve. The SNAP OF COTTON - MARGARET looks at them in a cold fury...

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: SILENCE-
dialogues.text: MARGARET nods to the seamstress, dismissing her-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you. You saved the day once again, Crawfie, you’re an angel. MARGARET straightens her cuff, testing the button, as the meeting slowly disbands and the MINISTERS move away.

dialogues.speaker: HOWE
dialogues.text: You can’t close down a discussion because it’s not what you wish to hear.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I don’t expect everyone just to sit there and agree with me. But what kind of leader am I if I don’t try to get my own way - to do what I know to be right.

dialogues.speaker: HOWE
dialogues.text: Yes. But Margaret, one must be careful of testing one’s colleagues’ loyalty too far. MARGARET glances up watching the MINISTERS disappearing, in whispered conversation, like conspirators. (ARCHIVE FOOTAGE) Rioting in Brixton, burning cars, huge civil unrest -

dialogues.speaker: TV JOURNALIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We are now one split nation, with a huge gulf dividing the employed from the unemployed. (ARCHIVE FOOTAGE) Protest marches, ‘People’s March for Jobs', ‘No pit closures” -  65

dialogues.speaker: UNION ACTIVIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Thatcher plan is to break the Trade Union movement.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There must be closures of uneconomic coal mines, we seek only an efficient industry. (ARCHIVE FOOTAGE) violent clashes between protesting miners and police -

dialogues.speaker: MINER'S WIFE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The miners are being starved back to work, the need is desperate! INT. CORRIDOR. HOUSE OF COMMONS. 1981. DAY. MARGARET sweeping along an endless corridor, surrounded by her cabinet, hard on her heels. HOWE, HESELTINE, PYM, PRIOR and OTHERS. MARGARET talking, they hang on her every word.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There are those who would say hold back, there are those who would make us retreat -— INT. CONFERENCE CENTRE BRIGHTON. 1980. Margaret mid speech.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: But we shall never give in to them. We shall never waver, not for a second, in our determination to see this country prosper once again. The party faithful erupt in cheers, seconded by all Margaret’s courtiers on the platform. PYM, PRIOR, HESELTINE, HOWE and above all DENIS, applauding as if their lives depended on it. INT. LADIES. HOUSE OF COMMONS. 1980. DAY. MARGARET sits clutching the sink, a light sweat breaking across her forehead. She looks up-

dialogues.speaker: NEWS READER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A car bomb has exploded outside Harrods department store, killing six people and injuring 71.  66

dialogues.speaker: NEWS READER 2, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Eleven soldiers died today when two bombs were detonated during military parades in Hyde Park and Regent’s Park. Seven horses also died in the blasts. INTERCUT (ARCHIVE FOOTAGE) bombed buildings, horses lying dead in the street, an IRA banner.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS READER 3, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The IRA have claimed responsibility. INT. BEDROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. NIGHT. MARGARET lost in restless sleep- INTERCUT (ARCHIVE FOOTAGE) IRA graffiti scrawled on a wall, paramilitaries fire guns, sirens wail. INT. CONFERENCE CENTRE BRIGHTON. 1980. Margaret on the podium.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: And now, it must be business as usual. THE BRIGHTON GRAND HOTEL. INT. SITTING ROOM. SUITE. GRAND HOTEL. 1984. NIGHT. DENIS in pyjamas, brushes his teeth in the bathroom. He glances at MARGARET through the open door as she sits, still in evening dress, working on her speech.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Come on love, get to bed. I don’t know why you do this to yourself every year, it’s a speech at conference, not the Magna Carta! She looks up, distracted.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Time to call it a day, darling. It’s ten to three, for God’s sake.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I know, I’m coming DT. Nearly there -

dialogues.speaker: BOOM
dialogues.text: 67 An almighty explosion rips through the room; wood, glass, furniture splinters, curtains flay from the walls. The fall of plaster, devastating, the hotel room obliterated, reduced to a smoking, dusty rubble. MARGARET stands ghostlike, covered in debris.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calling out) Denis! MARGARET searching through the haze of fallen plaster, covered with dust, slowly clearing to reveal-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (more desperate) Denis- there you are. Are you alright? DENIS ghostlike, covered in dust, still in his pyjamas, holding up an obliterated pair of shoes.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: My shoes! Beyond, the wall of the bathroom entirely blown away - The CAW of gulls- EXT. GRAND HOTEL. BRIGHTON. 1984. NIGHT. Chaos outside the Grand Hotel in the aftermath of the bomb. The WHIR of SIRENS- DENIS and MARGARET sit in their car, looking out in silent shock at the devastated Grand hotel, reflected on the glass of the car windows.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That’s when I thought I’d lost you. A TELEPHONE RINGS CUTTING THROUGH FROM ANOTHER TIME... INT. BEDROOM. HOUSE. CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. NIGHT. MARGARET wakes with a start, confused and fumbles for the telephone by her bed-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (picking up phone) Mark?... Hello darling... No, I’m fine... I’m very well...  68 MARGARET squints, fingers fumbling for DENIS’ watch.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How is... How’s... Sarah?... And the children. .? MARGARET sits up -

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: »..Oh... You can’t... That’s a pity... I was hoping to see you... No really darling... That’s fine... Of course... another time Lovely Darling... Can’t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: wait...Yes... MARGARET suddenly relents, a flicker of sudden and urgent need, caught in her eyes-—

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) Mark? Silence- MARK gone. MARGARET hangs up, stares at-— I Whistle A Happy Tune from the King and I just audible- INT. DRAWING ROOM.CHESTER SQUARE.PRESENT.NIGHT. MARGARET stands in the doorway, a jaunty “I Whistle A Happy Tune” seeping from the television.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: That was Mark. Not able to come.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: (cutting in) Boy’s always going AWOL.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Well it costs him a great deal to fly everyone up here.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: There you go, making excuses for him. Now look where it’s got you. DENIS stands dressed in dinner jacket and bow tie as he reads the back of “The King and I” DVD.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you know Yul Brynner was a gypsy from Vladivostok?  69

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes. He moved to Paris when he was fourteen. He played the King of Siam 4,625 times on the London and Broadway stages. What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: (turning round shaking a cocktail) One likes to make an effort. A snifter?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: You're dead, Denis.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Ah. Well, if I'm dead... who are you talking to? Shall we dance ? He takes Margaret in his arms. The music changes to ‘Shall we Dance’ from ‘The King and I’ as DENIS takes a confused MARGARET in his arms and begins an expansive waltz round the room. The room turns. YOUNG DENIS dancing with the YOUNG MARGARET. Now its OLD DENIS dancing with OLD MARGARET again. DENIS loses his footing, and MARGARET lurches towards the desk where her eyes fall on figurines of Falklands soldiers. She stares hard.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS READER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Falkland islands, the British Colony in the South Atlantic, has fallen. Argentina claims its marines went ashore this morning as a spearhead to capture key targets, including the capital, Port Stanley. INT. STUDY. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1982. DAY. MARGARET sits, composed, staring up at a phalanx of military men and her ministers.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, the Argentinian Junta - which is a fascist gang - has invaded our sovereign territory. This cannot be tolerated. May I make plain my negotiating position. I will not negotiate with criminals or thugs. The Falkland islands belong to Britain, and I want them back. Gentlemen, I need you to tell me today if that is possible.  70

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL LEACH
dialogues.text: Possible... just, Prime Minister. We can have a Task Force ready to sail in forty-eight hours. MARGARET is visibly stunned.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Forty-eight hours?

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL LEACH
dialogues.text: But -

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: But?

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL LEACH
dialogues.text: We have a very narrow weather window. We can’t fight in winter down there. Nobody can. If we are going, we have to go now. INT. STUDY. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1982. DAY. MARGARET at her desk.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Why were the islands left without any naval protection?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN NOTT
dialogues.text: In the last round of Defence cuts we judged the risk of invasion to be small.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Did we?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN NOTT
dialogues.text: And if you remember, Prime Minister, you agreed that we should reduce the naval presence in the area to an absolute minimum. MARGARET taps her fingers against the map, with growing irritation. INT. CABINET. DOWNING STREET. DAY. MARGARET sits alone.  71 INT CORRIDOR. . CORRIDOR. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1982.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET is under attack.

dialogues.speaker: HOWE
dialogues.text: Margaret, the cost of sending 28,000 men and a hundred ships twelve thousand miles, almost to Argentina, will be absolutely crippling.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I don’t think we should be worrying about money at this point, Geoffrey.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY HOWE
dialogues.text: We can’t afford to go to war. INT. STUDY. LONDON. 1982. NIGHT. MARGARET sits alone.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL LEACH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We have to go now.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The government has now decided that a large task force will sail, as soon as all preparations are complete. INTERCUT (ARCHIVE FOOTAGE) the Task Force sets sail.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRAWING ROOM. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1982. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET paces, deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: MP 1, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Prime Minister we do still have three weeks before our ships reach the islands.

dialogues.speaker: MP 2, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: All we're saying is that we shouldn’t give up on trying to find a diplomatic solution. INT. CORRIDOR. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1982. DAY. A tea trolley and an American entourage surge down a Downing Street corridor.  72

dialogues.speaker: MP 1
dialogues.text: The U.S. Secretary of State has arrived, Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRAWING ROOM. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1982. DAY
dialogues.text: Haig and Margaret sit facing each other, flanked by senior ministers.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HAIG
dialogues.text: So you are proposing to go to war over these Islands. They’re thousands of miles away, a handful of citizens, politically and economically... insignificant, if you'll excuse me -

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Just like Hawaii, I imagine.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HAIG
dialogues.text: I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: 1941, when Japan attacked Pearl Harbour. Did America go cap in hand and ask Tojo for a peaceful negotiation of terms? Did she turn her back on her own citizens there because the islands were thousands of miles from mainland United States? No, no, no! We will stand on principle or we shall not stand at all.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL HAIG
dialogues.text: But Margaret with all due respect when one has been to war....

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: With all due respect sir, I have done battle every single day of my life, and many men have underestimated me before. This lot seem bound to do the same but they will rue the day. MARGARET turns to a tea trolley close by-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, shall I be mother? HAGUE looks confused, MARGARET lifting the teapot-  73

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tea, Al, how do you take your tea? Black or white? INT. CENTRE OF OPERATIONS. 1982. DAY. NAVAL MEN murmuring messages quietly to NAVAL ATTACHES. Male lips to male ears, something MARGARET has seen all her life. FRANCIS PYM and JOHN NOTT stand near MARGARET. INTERCUT (STOCK FOOTAGE) the naval fleet sails towards the Falklands. A map of South Georgia and the Falkland Islands. Model boats sit on the water, flags sit on the islands. Argentinian flags. MARGARET stares at the map. A whispered message to one of the ATTACHES. He moves a model boat on the map a few inches, leading a fleet of smaller model boats.

dialogues.speaker: NAVAL ATTACHE 1
dialogues.text: The Argentinian ship the General Belgrano and her escorts are pursuing course 273 degrees toward the Argentinian mainland. We are tracking it with our submarine HMS Conqueror. He points to a model submarine at some distance from the Argentinian boats.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Is this ship a threat?

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL FIELDHOUSE
dialogues.text: Both of these ships are carrying Exocet missiles, Prime Minister. Just yesterday they launched- then aborted- an attack inside the exclusion zone. There is a risk they could try it again.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS PYM
dialogues.text: The Belgrano is sailing directly away from the islands. Can it really be regarded as a threat ?

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL FIELDHOUSE
dialogues.text: She’s been changing course continually. There’s a strong possibility that they’re attempting a pincer movement on our carrier group. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL FIELDHOUSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I advise that we engage them: hit the Belgrano as a warning to the others. Send them all back to port. MARGARET turns to JOHN NOTT and FRANCIS PYM.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCIS PYM
dialogues.text: It'll play badly internationally. We’ll be seen as aggressors. She stares at the map once more. One of the men supervising the map moves the model of the Belgrano a fraction further North.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN NOTT
dialogues.text: This will be an escalation, Prime Minister. She looks to LEACH.

dialogues.speaker: LEACH
dialogues.text: If there is to be an escalation, it’s better that we start it.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: It is steaming away, Prime Minister. Everyone is staring at MARGARET. Even the ASSISTANTS bustling in the background have stopped and are listening. Male faces turned to her. She herself seems caught in a pincer movement between the politicians and the servicemen.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Sink it.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DOWNING STREET. 1982. NIGHT
dialogues.text: TV Footage A flash of a torpedo cutting through the water. A thunderous explosion. Flashes of television images- striated and blurry- the Belgrano listing in the water. Reports of the sinking read out by the MOD’s Announcer. INT. DRAWING ROOM.CHESTER SQUARE.PRESENT.NIGHT. MARGARET and the Falklands figurine, silhouetted against the dawn light.  75

dialogues.speaker: INT. DOWNING STREET. 1982. NIGHT
dialogues.text: TV Footage CLOSE now - we see a man on fire, burning. VOICES mixing in and out. TV JOURNALIST V.O. «+. HMS Sheffield, a Type 42 destroyer, was attacked and hit late this afternoon by an Argentine missile...

dialogues.speaker: TV JOURNALIST V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...it is seen as a retaliation for the sinking of the General Belgrano, in which over 300 Argentinian sailors died... MARGARET'S eyes shining, as if with tears. A soft knocking at the door. She dabs them away quickly.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN NOTT
dialogues.text: Prime Minister - JOHN NOTT enters.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN NOTT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Latest casualty figures from the Sheffield. He hands her a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) I must write to them.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN NOTT
dialogues.text: Prime Minister?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: The families. I must write to them... INT. DOWNING STREET. STUDY. 1982. NIGHT. MARGARET at her desk, looks up at Pym.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Foreign Secretary...

dialogues.speaker: PYM
dialogues.text: I’ve just been briefed by Admiral Fieldhouse. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: PYM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He told me bluntly that if the Argentinians are prepared and willing to risk their aircraft, they have enough missiles to cripple most of our fleet. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN NOTT
dialogues.text: President Reagan and President Bellaunde of Peru have some new proposals for the peace plan -

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (sharply) The peace plan? There will be no appeasement. This is a war. A war they started and by God, we will finish. Shall I tell you what I’m going to write to every single one of these families, these heartbroken families? I am going to tell them that no British soldier will die in vain for the Falklands. INTERCUT (STOCK FOOTAGE) muddy mass graves as the Falklands dead are buried.

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY VOICE
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Colonel Jones. Captain Wood. Captain Dench. Lieutenant Farlaine. Corporal Hardman. Corporal Sullivan. Corporal Briar. MARGARET writes to each of the families.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As the only Prime Minister in the history of our country who is also a mother with a son of my own, I can imagine your agony, and your grief. INTERCUT (STOCK FOOTAGE) troops march through barren landscapes, helicopters hover, a British flag.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Prime Minister, we have secured the beachhead -

dialogues.speaker: NEWS ANNOUNCERS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The Argentinian troops are demoralized and ill equipped...The paratroops have taken Goose Green...  77

dialogues.speaker: RADIO VO
dialogues.text: Shortly after dark last night, our forces executed what our Commander in Chief has called a brilliant surprise night attack. MARGARET sits at a desk in Downing Street, listening to the news reports. A hand turns off the radio.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Thatcher, bed. He heads down the hall, MARGARET following behind.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO
dialogues.text: From their new positions, our forces can see large numbers of Argentine soldiers retreating and streaming back into Port Stanley. Our forces are moving forward to exploit their success. INTERCUT (ARCHIVE FOOTAGE) Victory! The Union Jack is raised over Port Stanley. The task force return to England to scenes of jubilation. Embraces, balloons, joyful embraces. INT. CAR. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1982. DUSK. MARGARET peering out, a sea of union jacks and bunting. Cheers, the street lined as the car pulls into Downing Street-— The blur of noise, cheering, jostling banners THEN the shroud of black uniforms suddenly encasing the car, blocking out the light- The jaunty distant sound of a military band playing-

dialogues.speaker: DENIS 0/S
dialogues.text: Well done, M. The car door swings open- A CACOPHONY of CHEERS, APPLAUSE, just audible far off, as MARGARET steps out into the street, the CAMERA follows her out peering up at- DOWNING STREET STAFF leaning out of No 10 windows, waving flags and cheering- MARGARET’s gaze lingering on HOWE and PYM amongst them, smiling with congratulations, clearly now part of the victory celebrations.  78

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET O/S
dialogues.text: We congratulate the men and women of the armed Forces for their skill, bravery and loyalty to this country. INT. HOUSE OF COMMONS CHAMBER PARLIAMENT. 1982. Prime Minister’s Questions. MARGARET is at the Dispatch Box fighting it out with MICHAEL FOOT. GEOFFREY HOWE IS BESIDE HER.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: We were faced with an act of unprovoked aggression and we responded as we have responded in times past: with unity, strength and courage, sure in the knowledge that though much is sacrificed, in the end, right will prevail over wrong. Huge cheers and “hear hears” from the Conservative benches. MICHAEL FOOT shifts uncomfortably on the benches opposite. She is unstoppable.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I put it to the Honourable Member opposite that this is not a day for him to carp, find fault, demand inquiries- they will happen I can assure him of that for we have nothing to hide- no, this is a day to put difference aside, hold one’s head high and take pride in being British. Barnstorming cheers. We see MICHAEL FOOT, utterly outmaneuvered by her speech. The Labour benches sit silent.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON PRESENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: DENIS springs in the air wearing a paper union jack hat, blowing a party hooter.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: GOTCHA! Well that paid off old girl! Your ratings soared! From the most hated Prime Minister of all time to the nation’s darling...The world was at your feet, and Britain was back in business!  79 INT. BALLROOM. WHITE HOUSE. WASHINGTON. 1981. NIGHT. QUICKFLASH: A glittering ballroom- MARGARET waltzing, caught in REAGAN’s arms, fleetingly passing- DENIS looking on, from the sidelines, drink in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET’S motorcade streaks through the rainy street, Union Jack flying. MARGARET shakes hands with Indira Ghandi. Denis is presented with the pink turban. Newspaper headlines scream PROFITS, PROFITS, PROFITS! MARGARET, triumphant on the podium at party conference. MARGARET shakes hands with Gorbachev. The Berlin Wall comes down.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS READER
dialogues.text: The Berlin Wall has fallen. The gates have opened! The police are making no attempt to stop people as they go through. Headlines: BOOMING BUSINESS! MAGGIE’S MILLIONAIRES!

dialogues.speaker: INT. EMBASSY BALLROOM. 1979. NIGHT
dialogues.text: MARGARET dancing with KENNETH KAUNDA of ZAMBIA, DENIS stands on the touchlines toasting them - a fruity cocktail in his hand. INT. HOUSE OF COMMONS STAIRWAY, 1990. DAY. MARGARET hurries down the stairs, her cabinet in tow.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I don’t agree in any measure!

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY HOWE
dialogues.text: But Prime Minister the question of the European single currency will come up.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I don’t think the country is ready for it yet.  80

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY HOWE
dialogues.text: But we cannot bury our heads in the sand...

dialogues.speaker: NEWS JOURNALIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A lot of Conservative MP’s and Ministers are saying - EXT. HOUSE OF COMMONS. LONDON. DAY. A journalist stands outside the Commons making his report.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: - that there must be a change in that style of management. That Mrs Thatcher must listen more, and on occasion, give in. INT. HOUSE OF COMMONS HALLWAY, 1990. DAY. MARGARET moving swiftly down the hall, leaving her cabinet in her wake.

dialogues.speaker: PYM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The point is, Prime Minister, I don’t think we can sell the idea of a tax that asks everyone to pay the same.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Our policies may be unpopular, but they are the right policies.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER 1, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Prime Minister I just don’t think we can ask the poorest of the poor to pay the same amount of tax as a multi-millionaire.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CABINET ROOM. DOWNING STREET. 1990. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET, seated at the wide cabinet table surrounded by a subdued CABINET. Most of the familiar old faces - PYM, HESELTINE, etc. All now gone. HOWE the last enduring minister. She casts a gimlet-eye over the GREY-SUITED MEN around her.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: There it is again! Why not?  SILENCE. 81

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER 1
dialogues.text: Because -

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER 2
dialogues.text: Because people... on the whole... think that the tax is manifestly unfair.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Nonsense. Arrant nonsense. This is a simple proposition. In order to live in this country, you must pay for the privilege- something, anything! If you pay nothing, you care nothing. What do you care where you throw your rubbish? Your council estate is a mess, your town, graffiti, what do you care? It's not your problem , it's somebody else's problem- it's the government's problem! YOUR problem is, some of you, is that you haven't got the courage for this fight. You haven’t had to fight hard for anything. It's all been given to you- and you feel guilty about it! Well, may I say, on behalf of all those who HAVE had to fight their way up, (and who don't feel guilty about it) we resent those slackers who take, take, take, and contribute nothing to the community!

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I see the same thing, the same cowardice in our fight within the European Union, to retain British sovereignty of Britain, the integrity of the pound! Some of you want to make concessions. I hear some of you agree with the latest French proposals. (beat) Well, why don’t you get on a boat to Calais? Yes, why don't you put on a beret, and pay 85% of your income to the French government! She has subdued them utterly. The silence is terrible.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right. What can we realistically hope to achieve by the end of session, Lord President? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And why have we not made more progress to date? What is that? Is that the timetable? I haven't seen that. May I see it?

dialogues.speaker: HOWE
dialogues.text: Here it is, Prime Minister. Of course. HOWE pushes the papers over to her. She picks up a pencil, starts to read. The MINISTERS watch as, quickly, she starts to score through the words.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: The wording is sloppy here, and here.

dialogues.speaker: HOWE
dialogues.text: If you say so.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I do say so.

dialogues.speaker: HOWE
dialogues.text: It's merely a first draft... MARGARET looks down at the paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous. There are two “T's” in “committee”! She presses so hard that her pencil breaks, so she shoves the paper back towards him, stabbing a finger at the offending word.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is shameful. Shameful! I can’t even rely on you fora simple timetable! Are you unwell? Yes you are unwell. Give me the pencil, give it to me! MARGARET snaps her fingers at HOWE, gesturing for his pencil, scratching away, ringing the offending word again and again. The MINISTERS stare at the scene appalled, utterly and wretchedly embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If this is the best you can do I had better send you to hospital, and I shall do your job as well as my own and everyone else’s. Gentlemen. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As the Lord President has come to cabinet unprepared, I am obliged to close this meeting. She waits for them to take their leave, but they sit there, frozen.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good morning! Slowly, the men gather their papers and file out of the room, leaving MARGARET alone. She sits, gathering herself, hands shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEAD, grimacing with one eyeball blinded and the other detached and hanging bloody on a cheek.

dialogues.speaker: ANGRY CROWD
dialogues.text: (chanting) Can’t pay, won't pay! Can’t pay, won’t pay! Can’t pay, won’t pay! INT. CAR. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1990. DAY. MARGARET peering out- ANGRY PROTESTORS slapping the glass as they pass, the sense of the car being attacked. The smear of smashed egg against the window screen.

dialogues.speaker: PROTESTORS
dialogues.text: Out... Out... Out... MARGARET sinks back into her seat as the car, is jostled either side by a blur of colour, the bang of fists against glass, the roar of the crowd -

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TRAFALGAR SQUARE. LONDON. 1990. DAY
dialogues.text: (ARCHIVE FOOTAGE) Relentless images of violence over this. Mass riots. PROTESTORS charging POLICE LINES. POLICE on HORSEBACK trying to force the PROTESTORS back. One of them - a GIRL - caught out, goes down with her placard, is trampled beneath the horses’ hooves, horribly. RIOTERS with blood streaming down their faces. Banners - DEATH TO MAGGIE. OFF WITH HER HEAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie... Maggie... Maggie. Out... out... out. With a WHOOSH of flames the north side of Piccadilly Circus goes up in flames. Smoke and blood and fire everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: INT. OFFICE DOWNING STREET. 1990. DAY
dialogues.text: Late afternoon- MARGARET sits, silently working. HOWE enters, MARGARET barely looks up from working-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Geoffrey-

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY
dialogues.text: My letter of resignation. HOWE slides a letter down on her desk- MARGARET looks down at the thick envelope.

dialogues.speaker: GEOFFREY HOWE
dialogues.text: Our differences, I’m afraid, cannot be reconciled. MARGARET resumes working- HOWE waits and waits and waits- The SCRATCH of MARGARET’s pen, she works on, refusing to stop for him. INT. CHAMBERS. HOUSE OF COMMONS. LONDON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howe stands in Parliament, reading his resignation speech:

dialogues.speaker: HOWE
dialogues.text: I have done what I believe to be right for my party and my country. The time has come for others to consider their own response to the tragic conflict of loyalties with which I have myself wrestled for perhaps too long.  85 INT. HALLWAYS. HOUSE OF COMMONS. LONDON. MARGARET walks alone down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER 1, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Geoffrey's speech in the House of Commons was devastating.

dialogues.speaker: MINSTER 2, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: - just couldn't take any more of the bullying. INT. CORRIDOR - HOUSE OF COMMONS. LONDON. 1990. DAY. MARGARET’s POV as she moves along the corridors of power.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER 3, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He was almost inviting someone to challenge her for leadership of the party. Fellow CABINET MINISTERS, unfamiliar backbenchers, the men in suits, all seem to avoid her gaze...then PYM in conversation with HOWE, abruptly terminated, as both men acknowledge her...

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER 4, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She behaved appallingly. I wouldn’t have spoken to my gamekeeper like that.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER 1, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don’t think she can survive this. INT. STUDY. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1990. NIGHT. MARGARET stands, watching the evening news, HESELTINE just visible on the TV screen-

dialogues.speaker: HESELTINE ON TV
dialogues.text: I’m here to announce my decision to put my name forward as leader of the Conservative party. I have nothing but admiration for our Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, but I believe our party and our country need a new leader. MARGARET turns to DENIS, who stands, clearly shocked, worst fears confirmed.  86

dialogues.speaker: TV JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: It’s extraordinary. The rules of the Conservative Party make it possible for Conservative MP’s to depose a sitting Prime Minister. MARGARET and DENIS on the sofa. She unwraps a sweet, eyes locked on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I am the Prime Minister. Turning to Denis.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (offering the packet) Sweetie? (STOCK FOOTAGE) WESTMINSTER in the moonlight -

dialogues.speaker: NEWS JOURNALIST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: As Conservative MP’s gather in Westminster to discus who they will back in the leadership contest, the Prime Minister said she would not be diverted from critical international affairs

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PARIS STREET. NIGHT
dialogues.text: With the Eiffel Tower illuminated behind him, Trevor MacDonald makes his report.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR MACDONALD
dialogues.text: Tonight in Paris Mrs Thatcher is among thirty four world leaders who came together to celebrate the end of the Cold War and herald the start of a peaceful new age of East/West cooperation. INT. GRAND HALL. PARIS. NIGHT. A magnificent painted hallway- MARGARET sweeping away from a dining room, regal in evening dress. INTERCUT — PARIS - A news journalist makes his report.  87

dialogues.speaker: NEWS JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: There’s a general feeling that Mrs Thatcher is going to win on the first ballot. We’re going to put it to bed tomorrow night, is how one of her campaign staff puts it.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GRAND HALL. PARIS. NIGHT
dialogues.text: MARGARET walks through a grand hall with her fellow PRESIDENTS and PRIME MINSTERS of the world, a lone woman amongst a sea of men.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS ON PHONE
dialogues.text: M, I really think you should come home and defend yourself old girl. Heseltine is campaigning ferociously.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET ON PHONE OOV
dialogues.text: I do think my time is best spent seeing an end to the Cold War, don’t you? After all this time they know what I stand for.

dialogues.speaker: TREVOR MACDONALD
dialogues.text: Will she, or will she not, be in the job tomorrow? A GRAND HALL - a formal dinner, MARGARET flanked by bow- tied Prime Ministers and Heads of State.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD OF STATE 1
dialogues.text: Margaret, they can’t touch you. LONDON STREETS - CABINET MINISTERS walking along trying to hide their features from prying eyes.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS READER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mrs Thatcher has failed to win enough votes to secure an outright win in the leadership contest and must now decide whether to put her name forward for the second round.

dialogues.speaker: NEWS READER 2
dialogues.text: As Mrs Thatcher leaves Paris for London to make a last ditch attempt to pull together support for her leadership, the ship may have sailed.  88 INT.DINING ROOM.CHESTER SQUARE. PRESENT. MARGARET pushes through the double doors into her dining room.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Treachery! Her cabinet are all around her dining room table. There is no seat for her. She moves round the table.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER 1
dialogues.text: We will never win another election led by that woman.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER 2
dialogues.text: We need a leader who listens.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER 3
dialogues.text: This isn’t about her, it’s about the party.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER 4
dialogues.text: One must know when to go.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER 1
dialogues.text: The question is, how does anyone put it to her? INT. DRAWING ROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. Close on a minister's face in the dim light.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: If you were to stand, I of course would vote for you Prime Minister She is at her desk in the PRESENT in Chester Square as one minister after another in interchangeable glasses slide into the chair in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER 2
dialogues.text: - of course would vote for you Prime Minister but I don’t think you can win. The loyalty of my colleagues cannot be counted upon.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: It was the people who put me here -

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER 3
dialogues.text: The loyalty of my colleagues cannot be counted upon.  154 89

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: - it’s up to them to tell me when to go. INT. STUDY. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1990. NIGHT. MARGARET stands, watching the evening news.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Margaret, you can’t let them do this to you. Please, boss. MARGARET looks at DENIS, with quiet surprise, hears the desperation in his voice, the crack-

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They’1l destroy you. MARGARET looks at DENIS, sees he is near to tears-—

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Throw in the towel now, love. Don’t let those bastards see you humiliated. You just won’t win, darling. Not this time.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Oh Denis. DENIS, fingers touch hers, she looks at him, sees the tender concern in his eyes. MARGARET smiles, determinedly steely under his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am the Prime Minister. 154 On her face as CASTA DIVA breaks through.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOUSE OF COMMONS. DAY
dialogues.text: MARGARET sits alone on the front bench. A stream of voices from the past -

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Order! Order!

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Right Honourable gentleman is afraid!

dialogues.speaker: NORTHERN VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is a naked strategy of closing some coal mines and then selling off -  90

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They believe in striking, I believe in working!

dialogues.speaker: IRISH VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is the woman who’s watched ten men on hunger strike starve themselves to death and never flinched!

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Despicable and cowardly -

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Cynical Falklands war -

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: More homeowners, more shareholders, more savings - The voices begin to blend into one another, white noise.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DOWNING STREET STUDY. 1990. EVENING
dialogues.text: MARGARET sips a whisky.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I offer my resignation after eleven and a half extraordinary years - INT. CORRIDOR. DOWNING STREET. LONDON. 1990. DAY. MARGARET descends the stairs like an operatic heroine, her hand gripping the banister of the staircase. Below the Downing St staff waiting to say goodbye. Many are in tears.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: -proud to have left Britain ina much better state than when we took office. She passes the photographs of her predecessors and stops to receive a gift, opening it-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's this then? A radio... How useful. She moves down the receiving line of staff. The floor is carpeted with roses. Men’s wet eyes. The door ahead. She is crying.  91 Finally reaching the door, MARGARET stands bracing herself. Denis’s hand on her shoulder standing behind.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Steady, MT. MARGARET nods, bracing herself. A hand on the door handle. As it swings open-

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: MARGARET stands staring at herself in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The greatest Prime Minister since Churchill deposed by a bunch of spineless pygmies!

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET VO
dialogues.text: All those years of taking the tough decisions, does any of it matter now?

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: It’s all been turned to mush!

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: What? DENIS lies on the bed behind her with the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: By these fools! These lily-livered pinkos!

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: These inept placators.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Very good! These vacillators.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Vacillators! Poll takers.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Popularity seekers.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: So busy taking the pulse of the public!

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Weak -  92

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (pulling down a rack of Denis’s black oxford shoes onto the floor) These...weak...weak...weak...wea.. -weak...Men! DENIS’s clothes are all over the room and the main cupboard is open and empty apart from shoes. There are several bin liners already filled with clothes.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t they know if you take the tough decisions, yes people will hate you today but they’1ll thank you for generations.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Or forget you entirely and chuck you out with the rubbish! MARGARET turns away from this thought and opens a last big chest of drawers.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET V/O
dialogues.text: (seizing shirts and jerseys and putting them on the floor) All I wanted was to make a difference in the world.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: And you did, love, you did. She sits at the end of her bed and opens a box she has found in Denis’s cupboard. There is a programme from ‘The King and I’ and a faded blue rosette from some long forgotten election campaign. A small flyer ‘Margaret Roberts. Conservative Candidate for Dartford’ and some childrens cards “to the world’s greatest Daddy love Mark and Carol.”

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET V/O
dialogues.text: All I wanted was for my children to grow up well and be happy - happier than I was certainly. And I wanted you to be happy of course. Were you happy, Denis? Tell me the truth. There is no response. MARGARET is momentarily lost in the room. Then, seized by some compulsion, she begins to pull out the rest of his clothes, shoving them into black bags. As shirts and trousers go in, quick flashes of Denis -  93 His youthful face, smiling at her at the opera. Laughing on the beach in Cornwall. At the door of Number 10, smiling at her. Sharing her bed. MARGARET looks up. Denis’s suitcase is on the bed. His coat and hat lying beside it. She folds his dressing gown - the one from the bathroom hook - tenderly and puts it on the top of the case.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Denis? Denis? And there he is by her side.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET V/O
dialogues.text: Here’s your bag. You’re all packed, sorted. She walks him to the bedroom door and gives him a gentle kiss. DENIS starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (seeing he is walking away in his socks) Denis wait...Where are your shoes? You can’t go without shoes! Not yet. DENIS straightens his hat.

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Steady.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes...Steady...

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: Steady the buffs -

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Steady...Steady the buffs... DENIS heading out.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 154d NO...Not yet...Denis. Wait...I 154d said I don’t want you to go yet. The endless corridor, MARGARET calling after DENIS-—  94

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Denis...Please...No...Not...Don’t. .-NO...I don’t...I don’t want to be on my own. DENIS turns back for a moment -

dialogues.speaker: DENIS
dialogues.text: You’re going to be fine on your own, love. (beat) You always have been. MARGARET calling out as DENIS reaches the window at the very far end of the house and appears to disappear into the white light-

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: (calling out) Denis!!

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM. HOUSE. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT.DAWN
dialogues.text: From above we see MARGARET lying dead asleep on the bed on a pile of DENIS’ clothes. The bed is surrounded by bulging black bin bags.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL OOV
dialogues.text: Mummy- CAROL looming over Margaret, looking horrified.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: My God, Mum. Are you alright? (opening the curtains) Mummy you should have called for help, silly old sausage. Have you not even been in your bed properly? You’ve done all this?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Yes, all sorted. Finished. MARGARET looks around her.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yes well don’t worry about all this. June and I will crack on with it.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: I was just going to get dressed.  95

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: ..-Shall I call someone, see if anyone can come over and do your hair? MARGARET looks at her warmly.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Oh. No, you do it. CAROL reacts, surprised but pleased. INT. KITCHEN. CHESTER SQUARE. LONDON. PRESENT. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET sit finishing a cup of tea. Hears Carol’s bustle in the downstairs hallway.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL OOV
dialogues.text: Right, I’m off June.

dialogues.speaker: JUNE
dialogues.text: OK. ‘Bye. She stands, picking up the cup. From behind-

dialogues.speaker: JUNE, (0.S)
dialogues.text: Oh let me do that, Margaret. MARGARET’s turns for a moment-— It is JUNE. MARGARET shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: No, dear, I’1l do it.

dialogues.speaker: JUNE
dialogues.text: Carol said you might go to the House of Lords today?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: No no. I’m not going anywhere. The sound of hot water running. CHINK of a teacup- MARGARET stands, washing up a tea cup. The SQUEAK of her wet cloth, working on a stubborn tea stain, puncturing the silence. The sound of birdsong and children playing drifts from the street outside.  MARGARET sets the cup aside, turns and walks out of the room, and out of sight.
